reviewText:
Knights of Pen & Paper, originally for iOS, is a turn-based RPG with a novel concept: you take on the role of real-life players in a tabletop game.  The camera is set behind a table where up to five of your characters are seated, with the dungeon master on the other side leading you through the story.  Dialogue tends to be humorous and frequently goes out of character.

The game begins with character creation, where you must assign your players a real-life persona and one of a dozen traditional RPG classes, each with four skills.  The actual gameplay takes place around your table, as if you‚Äôre in the middle of all the action, and consists of traveling to locations on a world map and completing quests, which are really just more battles in disguise.  In fact, the entire game is simply one battle after another and becomes very repetitive, very fast.

As expected, level-ups provide stat bonuses and allow you to upgrade your skills and wear better equipment.  Armor and weapons may only be improved at the blacksmith, but each character has four additional slots for equipping various accessories.  In addition to in-game shops, there is a ‚Äúreal-life‚Äù shop where you may purchase snacks that provide temporary buffs for your players, as well as decorations and furniture that confer permanent bonuses.

Overall, Knights of Pen & Paper is passable in the context of mobile gaming but completely forgettable when compared to quality games on the PC platform.  Considering the price is $9.99 on Steam vs a mere $2.99 on iOS and Android, it‚Äôs borderline offensive that the devs left in-app purchases in the game, allowing you to buy gold with your Steam wallet funds.  Such a shameless exhibit of its mobile origins is a fitting red flag for a game that also fails to break away from the shallow, repetitive gameplay those origins typically entail.

reviewText:
I admit, I miss tabletop gaming. I miss the DM trying to kill off my characters. I miss creating ridiculously out-of-the-box characters. Heck, I miss the days of popcorn, Mountain Dew, and just hanging out and rolling some dice. Those days have been gone for me quite some time ago, and yet playing a little game called Knights of Pen and Paper reminded me of those good old days.

Knights of Pen and Paper attempts to mimic tabletop gaming for an accessible audience. Players start by selecting three noobs to join the adventuring party, along with their class and starting skill. Like any tabletop RPG, as the adventuring party explores, kills baddies, and completes quests, they earn experience to level up and gain more skills. Each party member gets one skill point every time they level up and can only put points into one of four skills. While this creates simplicity for those unfamiliar with RPGs, it doesn't provide a lot of variety.

In fact, variety is what Knights of Pen and Paper struggles with throughout its twenty hour campaign. Although the backgrounds mimic an 8-bit style, there isn't much in terms of detail or design. The soundtrack loops, but it feels like there's only three tracks in the entire game. Although there's plenty of classes in the game, many of them are locked and the requirements for unlocking them appear random. The base classes ‚Äî paladin, mage, cleric, etc. ‚Äî while classic, are trapped with only four skills, which wouldn't be the case in tabletop gaming.

While variety isn't the game's strong suit, accessibility is. It provides a simple turn-based battle system wherein players can select between attack, skill, defend, item, and flee. This makes for an easy learning experience, but it lacks any real depth that a tabletop game has. The game is also surprisingly grindy, and while it does a great job of teaching players what to expect in encounters (usually enemies three to five levels higher than the adventuring party), it's a bit crazy how much players will have to stop and grind because it's not entirely on par with the party's level. It feels like the developers set out to make a simple RPG to give players the feel of tabletop gaming, but the combat could have benefitted from actual dice rolls on screen to indicate whether or not the player's characters succeeded or fail in their actions. However, with the grindy combat, perhaps adding dice rolls would have just made everything take longer than provide more accessibility. Still, the combat lacks depth and it needs something else to make it a more engaging process.

Dice rolling does exist within Knights of Pen and Paper, it's just not as frequent as it should be. Dice rolls occur when players travel between areas, failures leading to battles, successes leading to safety. Dice rolls occur when players are mining for grindstones or moving through dungeons. These elements are done well and are fairly straightforward, but this game would really benefit if it was implemented into all actions, especially if its goal is to mimic tabletop games. What's further disappointing is the campaign itself. While the writing is charming and hilarious, the majority of the quests are either escort missions, collecting items, slaying some bad dudes, or traveling from place to place for plot purposes. The amount of backtracking in this game is brutal and inexcusable, and even the adventuring party complains about it. It goes back to that problem of accessibility versus variety ‚Äî on one hand, the campaign should be easy to learn and follow along, on the other hand there should be more to do than then the standard affair. The charm in the writing, and even its awkward translation errors, can only go so far and will likely leave veteran RPGamers wanting something more substantial.

However, Knights of Pen and Paper does succeed in its overall atmosphere. Players get the sense of gamers hanging out, bantering, and asking to pass the Mountain Dew. There is an overal sense that the Dungeon Master is out to kill the adventuring party, and the back and forth within the writing really does work well. The graphics and music, though overly simplistic, are vibrant and give the feeling that players are on an adventure and there is loot to be had. The game is also a fantastic time waster because in its lack of depth it success at being the type of mindless game where players find themselves going, just one more quest." Considering all of the game's flaws

reviewText:
Knights of Pen and Paper is a fantasy RPG, which plays like tabletop RPGs. The twist is that you're playing as both the dungeon master and the players. Basically that means you can decide yourself what kind of quests you want (to some extent) and how difficult you want to make the fights by choosing how many enemies you want to fight against. And because the game is like tabletop RPGs, there are several situations where you'll throw a virtual D20 dice.

When you first start the game you get to choose from about 10 characters to be the players and 5 classes for them. Each character has a different passive bonus that increases some attributes, which actually leads to choosing the characters based on the bonuses and the class you're going to pick. When starting a new game you get to choose 2 players for free and the remaining 3 seats in the table you can fill by buying the players with in-game gold. You can swap the players in places that have a tavern.

If I remember correctly, you first have 5 classes available, but you can unlock a few more by completing side-quests. You can only have one of each class, so for example you can't have 5 warriors as your party. You wouldn't want to either. The reason being that each class has its purpose. Some classes are healers, some are tanks and the rest are either melee fighters or spellcasters of some description. Each class has 4 skills, which are either passive or spells and skills that you can use during combat. The passive skills usually boost some attribute, but some of them also have special stat boosts like life steal. The active skills are pretty basic fantasy RPG skills. You can increase one of the skills every time you level up, which just made the skills more powerful or increased the attribute bonus. So it isn't very deep skill system.

The combat is turn based and the players and the enemies all have a box either on top of or below the sprite, which shows the number of their turn. On the player's turns you choose to either attack, use a skill/spell, use an item, defend or run away from the battle. You quite rarely want to use anything other than a skill or spell, because those are the most effective way for beating the enemies. As I mentioned earlier, you get to choose how many and what kind of enemies you want to fight against. Once you buy a certain item from a special shop you can fight 7 enemies at a time, but before that the maximum was 5, I think. I bought that item very early on and didn't check the maximum amount before that. The enemies you can choose from vary quite a lot and you can often choose to fight tougher elite monsters, which give better rewards.

I thought the combat was quite fun, but it got kinda boring after 8 hours because in the end it was just the same thing over and over again. At least they kept things fresh with different enemies. The difficulty ramped up quite a lot after about halfway into the game, when the enemies suddenly became very high-leveled compared to the players. Surprisingly enough, I could survive against much higher level enemies than my players were provided I only fought against 3 at a time. It could take a long time to kill them all, but I still could do it. I suppose I played it quite safe since most of the time I fought battles I knew I could win and as a result my whole party died only 3 times during the time I played the game.

When you're not in combat you can choose from several options depending on your location in the world. In almost every place you can choose to rest, start a quest specific to the location, use items, check the equipment of the players or travel to some other place. Cities usually also have shops for buying potions and equipment, a tavern and a blacksmith. The blacksmith can upgrade your equipment, but you shouldn't do that until you have increased the blacksmith's level enough for the odds to be on your side. The upgrading is chance based and it happens by throwing the dice. The range of winning" numbers increases as the blacksmith levels up

Traveling costs some gold and every time you move on the map

reviewText:
There isn't much to this game; it's just a simple, humorous 8-bit turn base game. There is a lot of hilarious commentary and for the most part character development is nice. I know that the dialog is all pre-set, but it makes the characters pretty funny and sassy. One of my favorite aspects is the ridiculous dirty jokes made through-out the game.

There's a ton (I mean A LOT) of characters and classes to choose from. There's a nice little upgrade setting that lets you have a few different moves and upgrade them.

It's just like any other turn base game. It's fun, it's cheap and the developers are extremely nice and enjoy interacting with their fans; which is always great. I would definably get this game while on sale.

reviewText:
This has the appearance of a nostalgic D&D tabletop setting, but is more like a poorly-translated turn-based JRPG, where tactical positioning and well-timed skill choices are not the focus. Instead, players find themselves killing hordes upon hordes of monsters to make numbers go up so they can kill bigger hordes of scarier monsters. The story tries to be humorous about a D&D group finding the line between fantasy and reality blurred with numerous shoe-horned cameos, but the writing itself is unnatural to the point that it feels like a high-schooler's fan-fiction. In fact, if you're looking for a game the emulates the D&D experience, I recommend Cardhunter, a free-to-play tactical game with better writing and more involved gameplay.

Even if you're in the market for a mindless grind-a-thon, don't buy this on the PC. Opt for the mobile version instead, since the game also constantly puts you through miniscule but unskippable animations that would be more bearable if you could look out the window while they play. Hell, I'd recommend other mobile games entirely, but some people like their skinner boxes and this is one of the skinneriest boxes I've ever seen.

P.S.: This game *had* micro-transactions, but those have been removed. According to an anonymous source (see comment), the microtransaction was originally forced on by a publisher. A sad case of publisher overruling developer control. The game is still a terrible grind though.

reviewText:
The first 4-5 hours are great, when you are exploring the world, unlocking new classes and testing different groups. Sadly, afterwards the game becomes a massive grind of fighting the same enemies over and over, going back and forth the same places and every battle feels exactly the same...

It has a lot of flavor and cool references, but still I couldn't even force myself to reach the end of the game. There's micro-transactions in-game, but honestly they don't get in the way, the massive grind at end-game and lack of interesting battles are this game's major flaws.

reviewText:
I really loved the game. It took me 20 hours to complete, which includes a restart after some hours when I had unlocked more interesting characters than the starting lineup. I'll have to go back and finish it with the ones I missed in the future.

The game was a lot of fun, and definitely worth the asking price. It made me smile many times, what with all those wacky references to other games and developers. I bought the Deluxe edition to support the developers as much as I could, as I had researched the game prior to buying it, and I'm glad I did. The extra gold you start with is nice (but doesn't provide any sort of advantage other than when you get a full lineup but let's face it, it doesn't matter).

If you're on the fence, then just go ahead and spend the 10 euro or whatever the price is in your region. It's a fun throwback to the golden ages of gaming, and it's just well done through and through. I doubt very much you'll regret it. Don't worry about the ingame cash shop. I never used it, and NEVER had a reason to. You earn redicilous amounts of gold in this game just doing the main quest line, and the extra gold you can buy for real money is so useless, I'm puzzled why they added it at all.

reviewText:
The Good: Fun premise, mixing the tropes of D&D-style tabletop gaming and Final Fantasy-esque RPG combat, with the usual nods to post-Tolkien high fantasy worlds. There's a solid dose of fun pop culture references (from Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and Super Mario Brothers in the sewer dungeon, to Pirates of the Caribbean and the Creature from the Black Lagoon in the seaside areas). And it's not just gratuitious name-checking either -- all of it is properly statted out and integrated into the gameplay.

The Bad: Admittedly, it's hardly ground-breaking stuff, especially if you're partial to comedy/parody RPGs. It's not quite as witty or clever as its web-based counterparts like Kingdom of Loathing[kingdomofloathing.com] or Card Hunter[game.cardhunter.com]. But even as someone who liked both those games, I wasn't disappointed -- I'm now at 10 hours play time and counting.

The Ugly: Less-than-ideal game balance. It definitely appears to favor particular player/class combos over others, to the point that it's damn near impossible to last the higher levels with certain oddball party compositions, which kinda takes out some of the fun.

reviewText: Imagine playing table top D&D, and getting sucked into the world of Nintendo, where you are still playing Table top D&D, only you are playing it as an NES video game. That pretty much sums up this game in a nutshell, only you play it on the PC. It looks like an old school NES game, but incorporates the table top D&D feel, Very interesting concept. Much different than the early video game D&D adventures, this game tries to stay true to old school D&D. I thought it was a fun little game and would recommend it, because it can be picked up for next to nothing or even free and if you enjoy anything D&D related, you should at least give it a try. Get ready for a Nostalgia rush.

reviewText:
I enjoy the premise of this game, the core idea that it tries to emulate with a twist, a DnD session where you can customize and control the players and the room that the game takes place in, even the dungeon master.

I will say that the game does have charm and has a good art direction, though I would say that there should have been more effort in the pixel art. However, it has both condensed and distilled the core elements of pen and paper gaming to a level which is far too simplistic for me to enjoy. The combat is shallow, the quests are repetitive, and the stats and perks are shallow and hardly feel like they matter. The UI is also highly simplistic and does not even provide important information efficiently or at all.

I am sure that this is a fun bathroom game on a mobile device or something on the go, but the flaws of this game impeded my enjoyment of this game and cannot recommend this game to people who want an enthralling experience.

reviewText:
Cute concept for a game. Unfortunately, the novelty wears off fairly quickly, and the actual gameplay just doesn't hold up. Traditional jRPGs are carried by their characters and story, because the combat and mechanics thereof are so one-dimensional and stale.

So Knights of Pen and Paper has the same boring combat as any Dragon Warrior/Dragon Quest/Final Fantasy/etc game, but all the writing, charm, and polish has been replaced by easy jokes about RPG tropes.

If RPGs are played for the story, where's the story? I guess the gag is that there is no story, that this is the RPG stripped down and laid bare. I can buy that. But since there's no gameplay worth noting, does that joke really carry a game for 5+ hours?

I don't think it does. The premise is done a hundred times better by Half Minute Hero - which has all the same lazy RPG observational humor"

reviewText:
I can describe Knights of Pen and Paper as a Dungeons & Dragons simulator instead of your typical RPG. There is no exploration or movement. It is all menu and dialog based. The map is pretty segmented like a Mario map and there are not maps so much as there are quests. These quests revolve around typical and simplified RPG turn based combat. The catch is you also play your own dungeon master, so you can select your enemies to fight and how many you will fight. Its as if you're making your own busy work. The classes feel balanced, but the battles begin feel too long for the never ending grind that this game becomes. Unless you want to spend real money to buy in game gold.

The game has a lot of personalization. You start the game selecting characters and their classes. Each character has its own passive ability and then you assign a class. You can only have one of a class per party. Each class has 4 upgradeable abilities, some are passives like regenerate HP per turn and most are combat abilities. When you level up through experience defeating enemies, you can level up a skill. Leveling up skills increases the MP they use, so its a double edged sword where eventually you can only use a skill once or twice before you need to rest or use potions. There are items that will regenerate MP and HP along with increase maximums.

The combat abilities feel useful. Paladins have a leader strike that is a powerful attack. The strike will increase their threat to enemies driving the majority of attacks to that character. To balance the attention, the paladin has a temporary shield power, a flash heal for themselves and devotion that increases the base HP. A cleric can heal the entire party or focus healing on one character. They can also use a smite skill that damages an enemy and heals themselves. To round things out there is a weakening spell to debuff enemy attack power for three enemies. Mages have a single enemy damaging fireball that will burn them, damaging HP each turn. They also have a deep freeze that damages and stuns an enemy. Mages also have a meteor that damages an entire enemy party and finally a passive stream that increases the base MP. I can't cover all the classes, but they feel well rounded.

The classes have to feel well rounded, because the game is nothing but combat. A chess game between you and enemies that you chose to fight. The game has plenty of quests to give you and you can tackle them one at a time. Nothing that will stump you, since all the 'quests' seem to be collect X amount of Y or defeat X amount of Y enemies. Escort X from point A to B and then fight a battle. It wouldn't seem like such a grind if your travel had more exploration instead of moving along a line from location to location. There is some banter along the way, but its just your party sitting at a table facing a dungeon master with different beautiful backgrounds. The battles get long, even with better equipment. It gets frustrating when you complete a quest to kill 7 plants only to get another quest to kill 9 plants. Then that quest followed by another quest to get 19 carrots. How? By killing the same plants you've just slaughtered. You can always pick your quests, but its useless when you'll end up doing them all anyway.

When you visit a town, you don't walk to a store, you just click on an icon that will open up the store. The items are nice. Upgrading weapons and armor involves a gambling system. Sure it costs 150 gold to have a blacksmith upgrade your gear, but there's only a 35% chance he'll succeed. Seems like a gamble and a waste of gold. The blacksmith will get better with every try . You can even increase the blacksmith's experience by using grindstones that you'll buy or find in caves.

That leads me to warn you of this. Microtransactions. Why grind for gold when you can just buy it with real life money? The microtransactions aren't in your face or annoying, but they are there and some people have problems with that. If you want gold, go kill some enemies, there's nothing else to do in the game.

If someone in your party dies, that costs gold. Since resurrection costs gold, when your party gets wiped out and you don't have enough gold to resurrect one of them, that's it. It was originally a gameover, because the game will save itself preventing you from going back to a previous point when your party was alive. So you'd have to buy gold with real life money. Luckily, there is now a free continue that will resurrect everyone, but reset their level experience. I'm thankful of that. If you don't want to grind to level up your characters, you can always buy experience with gold. There is always a need for gold. Whether its experience, resurrection, traveling, or gambling to upgrade your equipment. Oh and don't forget buying stuff.

At some point, this game is busy work and you know some people are ok with that. In all, I would say its a fun game, but other RPGs are better. Since this is trying to be a Dungeons & Dragons simulator without being a true RPG its just lacking in some areas.

reviewText:
Don't let the complaints fool you. This is actually a great arcade classic turn-based RPG experience.

Think of the original Final Fantasy games, in a much more fun, comedic fashion, but still has the challenge, and core elements you love. You will go on grand adventures, fighting many various foes with a pretty good storyline.

There's options to increase the challenge for even greater rewards / xp, loot, etc. etc. vamping the difficulty that suits you.

It's hard to explain all the qualities that makes this game so cute, and enjoyable, but I think it's definitely something every RPG fan would love to play for a few hours.

The main downside people seem to complain about is that there's one very small in-game real money shop, which you can pay like $1-5 for in-game gold. The game is not balanced around this shop, and I've never once understood why it was in the game. Perhaps it's for stupid people" who make foolish decisions

reviewText:
This isn't a terribly bad game, but it's fun is very fleeting and you'll forget about it the minute you exit out of it.
The premise was cool and was the main reason I bought it but they really didn't do anything with it - the characters are all interchangable (literally) and the dialog seems to be aimed at kids - the humor is mostly refrencing things and changing one word or changing it slightly (Wizards of the East Coast, HAHAHAHA). You set your own pace on everything, like choosing which enemies you want to fight and how many, so the game never really suprises or challenges you. The quests are boring and all feel like sidequests (kill this many things, go here, collect this many things, blahblahblah). They've taken microtransactions out of the game but you can tell a lot of the mechanics were set up with those in mind.

They do have some neat things like the ability to buy upgrades and powerups for the 'real life' players, and these upgrades carry over different saves, but there isn't enough of this and you'll have most the things you want rather early on. The graphics are pretty nice as well, if you like the 8bit style.

This game is probably better played on a phone or mobile device, this isn't a terrible port but it shows it was made for a touch screen in mind - for example you have to select the enemy to attack every time. I'd recommend buying this on a mobile touch screen device, it'll prob cost less - also it'd be easier to play it in short bursts like it is prob meant to be played.

In short, they botched it.

reviewText:
First of all, there was an update that killed save files, which is a big problem for an RPG of this length.  I wasn't interested in replaying the first ten hours of the game, so I've never played it since then.  I'm not really sure what the developers were thinking.  It was an old game when the patch came out, so the loss of save files was definitely unexpected.

Also, it's pretty dumb that if you already have some of the DLC from buying the +1 Edition, you can't just buy the extra DLC you're missing without rebuying it with the base game.  Come on now.

As for the game itself, I would rate as so-so.  The theme and art is top-notch, but everything else becomes kind of a drag as you keep playing.  There's way too many boring encounters.  Some of the areas seem really poorly balanced-- I went into a dungeon with a level rating lower than my party's, and was basically insta-killed (had zero problems up to that point).  You might like it a little better than I did if you're a big fan of grindy RPGs, because there's a LOT of grinding.  What kept me playing was the witty writing, but it wasn't quite strong enough to carry the game on its own.

reviewText: I'm really bored at my computer one night and find a game that is having a sale that just covers my left over money from my steam wallet. There can be cheap situations where you die easily, but for me, it wasn't unbearable. I don't normally appreciate these kinds of games, with this being a major exception. Although I can't give it a high rating, I can at least recommend it to my friends and family.

reviewText: A great casual game. It really only has the one game mechanic, as if you're in a battle in a final fantasy game, or any turn-based RPG - Each turn you choose to battle / magic / item, and your party defeats monsters. An interesting aspect of this game is that you control the number and difficulty of most of the encounters. But graphically, there is not much beyond what you see in the trailer. Besides the world map, and the table where your party sits, you don't move around.\n\nIt could get boring for some, if you're not looking for an endless battle; but the game is as difficult or as easy as you choose to make it. I definitely think it's worth it. It's very easy to pick up and play a few minutes at a time, as there's no learning curve. There are enough random encounters, and it's well polished, this game will keep me entertained for hours.

reviewText:
This is a game you will love or hate depending on your tolerance for RPG tropes. The best parts are when it succesfully makes fun of the cliches of CRPG's while bringing a sense of humour about what makes the pen and paper versions so much fun. At its worst it IS those cliches. One of the things I really disliked was that to upgrade your characters standard weapons and armour costs a fortune at the blacksmith and requires extensive upgrades to get above a less than %50 chance of the upgrade being successful (Your money, which is in short suppy, is spent regardless). You can upgrade the chance by getting grindstones, but GRIND is the opperative word. Grindstones are only available in caves and there is only a precentage of getting one for each ore pile you click on. You will need to go back to these places again and again and again to try to get enough grindstones to raise the chance of an upgrade succeeding more than %50 of the time. I do like it, but with caveats. If you can tolerate the random grinding required, go for it.

Pros:
Good sense of humour
Graphics have a lot of charm
Chirpy retro music

Cons:
Grinding
Repetition
Rinse/repeat
Tear enducing upgrade system

reviewText: This game easily could have been a free-to-play-game, but once you start playing, you realize that it IS a game you can play without restrictions. The idea of a table in the middle of the screen sounded weird, but you actually don't notice it in mid-battle. This is an awesome game.\nIt's simple enough to just pick up and play, but you can still work out a winning strategy. Think of it like Pokemon. You can kinda ignore the stats and get through the game, but you can also maximize your team's potential by equiping certain items. So if you don't want to think about it, you can make it through, but if you do the math, you can do better. It's. Just. Awesome. You can go pretty much anywhere right from the start, but you'll probably die if you do. But that's still an option.\nI recommend reading a guide before playing, as there is some terms you probably won't understand, but it's smooth sailing from there.

reviewText:
It's like Dungeons & Dragons, minus the need for friends. One time I was playing this and 5 hours ended up passing before I realized it when I thought I had only been playing for 2 hours. 15/18

But seriously though, it's like DnD, except you control everything that happens, from how many enemies you fight in each encounter (most of the time) to which quests you do to how many characters you have in your party at one time.

It's a pretty meta game, calling upon/calling out various things you'd normally find in a DnD campaign and other tropes relative to table top RPGs, but at the same time it's pretty genre savvy in and of itself, so if you're familiar with these kinds of games, you'll probably get a kick outta the dialogue.

There's also a sequel available too if you like this then be sure to check that one out as well.

Maybe this game works well on a cellphone but to sit down and deliberately play it on a PC is laughable. The gameplay is so incredibly shallow you can win practically every encounter by closing your eyes and clicking your mouse unless you try to stack the odds against yourself (which you will since every fight is so simple) and even then your rampant clicking will only be broken up to cast a healing spell now and then. Everything at the store costs 1-5 coins and monsters drop a few coins here and there...but I started with like 5000 gold for some reason. I‚Äôm not entirely sure but I feel like the game tried to balance out the absence of micro-transactions of its mobile game counterpart by dumping all the gold in the world in my pocket and calling it square.

If this game has anything going for it, it‚Äôs the sprite work which is very pretty and the music is pleasant but everything is massively let down by how unstimulating the game feels. It's not a BAD game but its a pretty BLAH game
voteText: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Despite no mention of it anywhere, this game contains microstransactions that will make the game easier. This means that on top earning money through game sales themselves, the game is continually monetised through the sale of more in game currency. It also suggests that the difficulty and the amount of mindless grinding required in the game to progress is geared toward frustrating you into getting out your wallet to buy progress with real world cash.

This business model is unacceptable. If I pay money for a game I expect there to be a final transaction for me to enjoy the game as is. When I'm expected to buy my progress through the game on the other hand, under no circumstances do I want to pay money up front, especially not without being notified of these transactions. I don't want to pay a fair price for a game only to find out that I will have to invest a lot more to really enjoy it.

The game itself seemed clever at times, but I soon felt forced to either grind through enemies at a boringly slow pace or fork over real cash.

reviewText:
I picked up this game because it seemed to be a novel experience. Admittedly the first hour or so was very entertaining. The witty dialogue constantly breaks the fourth wall, and the Rollplay mechanics where fun for a while.

Unfortunately the gameplay does not change very much after the first hour. The quests lack any distinction(the game breaks all quests down into a few archetypes), the progression system deteriorates into bland stat increases(each character has only 4 abilities), and the game's pacing entices the player to utilize the game's microtransactions to level quicker or buy better gear.

There are unlockable characters, but to use them in the current playthrough you would need to spend some time leveling them from lvl 1 or use them in a a new playthrough.

After a while the game slows to an almost literal grind. Enjoyment is derived by being able to jump in and out of over a VERY long period of time. Haven't beaten it yet but, it's pretty light and shallow so far.

reviewText:
All the 90's references can't make up for Knights of Pen and Paper's grinding, mobile roots.

Pros: Graphics, Sounds, Controls
Cons: Gameplay, Story, Bugs

For fans of pixel graphics, Knights of Pen and Paper will not disappoint, although it may be a waste of most computers' potential.  The sounds and music fit well, although they may begin to grate after a few hours.  Control with the mouse and the smallish menus are perfect.

Unfortunately, the grindy, repetitive gameplay is where Knights of Pen and Paper shows its mobile roots.  The story isn't terrible, but lacks the great moments often had whilst playing true tabletop RPGs.  For achievement hounds, the Deluxe Edition is a must, as it provides a slightly better grinding area.  A number of achievement bugs ensure that the grind lasts many hours longer than it should.

Knights of Pen and Paper is a throwback game in many ways, but a number of flaws mar it severly.

5/10
voteText: 28 of 51 people (55%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition is an example of what is wrong with the gaming industry, publishers and developers working together to make a game that is less than a full and proper experience without first investing heavily in it.  In most cases, that means you must use real world money to make your game run the way it should in the first place.  Luckily the game gives players a choice, you have the choice to play the game a great deal, or to buy shortcuts to make the game better.  Everywhere you turn there is a price attached to everything, you can gain the currency with playing or with plastic, and playing takes way too long.

I would say that the game itself, when you ignore this horrible choice of microtransactions, is mediocre, not exceptional.  It has several novel ideas, but it lacks any real pay off, there is nothing revolutionary or deeply engaging about it.  Even the flavour text, the stuff you would hope would be most entertaining in a dungeons and dragons type of game feels weak and boring, as though the developers were not into it.

Overall, I was quite disappointed with this title and I don't think many people will be able to enjoy it.

reviewText:
As much as I wanted to be able to reccomend this game as at least a casual mindless fun type of title, it turns out that the game is not even sucessful at that. The game's premise of telling a story from the point of view of people playing a Tabletop RPG is played painfully straight without any humor involved other than the premise itself. The game also provides no attempts at being an authentic Tabletop RPG experience by being restrictively linear and having a fixed storyline. Speaking of which, the game's story has no sense of atmospheric or emotional depth and is paper thin, no pun intended, and is literally the most generic and bare bones story you can think of for a fantasy game. Again no attempts are made to actually make this interesting or relate it to the game's premise.

The gameplay is made up entirely of fetch quests that are normally reserved for sidequests, and there is no exploration included at all. The game will stop being fun after about an hour. Also the game features micro-transactions in the form of buying in game money with real world money, and the game's design seems to be based arpound making you use up as much in game money as possible. Traveling to new locations, reviving dead parteners both cost in game money despite making no logical sense why this should be the case. Up grading weapons is something that costs an absurd amount of money to attempt, but it starts out with only a 35% chance of working, and the only way to increase that percentage is to sucesfully upgrade weapons. Because of this, you will likely go through all your in game money really quickly, and seeing as how money takes a rediculously long time to farm in this game, it seems entirely likely that the idea was to get you to use the micro-transactions.

This game is not reccomended.

reviewText:
In a word: Avoid. Read on for reasons.

A game that simulates pen and paper RPGs? Sounds great, doesn't it? This game will do just that, but the Dungeon Master is largely unamusing, which leads to a mundane story. The comments your party makes are usually cheesy one-liners or memes, or video game references. You roll a d20 for quests, upgrading gear, getting grindstones in caves, resting in non-towns, and travelling, and failing a dice roll only makes the game more tedious. The battle system is all turn-based, and order is loosely based on initiative, but it's mostly random.

A more minor point though are the microtransactions for in-game gold which are COMPLETELY UNNECESSARY but for some reason every day some guy will complain about ermergerd microtransactions" in the community hub. The microtransactions are NOT REQUIRED at any point in the game; the microtransactions only help you by shaving off a few minutes of your time that would otherwise have been spent doing what you already have to do for the entire game. The microtransactions only give you gold. You get gold from fighting monsters.

For the obsessive
date: completionist players:\nAs of typing up this post there are at least 5 broken achievements out of 43. Apparently there have been inquiries sent to the developers asking when the achievements will be fixed
recommended:
and the answer provided was that the devs were busy working on another project that isn't Knights of Pen and Paper.

tl;dr:

Do not buy
hoursPlayed:
because:
1. Unoriginal plot
2. Ridiculously random
3. Unnecessarily tedious
4. Broken achievements"

reviewText:
This game pulls off imitating the tabletop experience well for good and for ill.

THINGS THS IS GAME DOES LIKE TABLETOP GAMING:
~Travel is quick because travel is boring.
~Travel is still something that you have to do too much.
~The NPCs that stand out remain well in your memory
~The NPCs that don't are all exactly the same re-skinned NPC, other than MAYBE half a dozen they are all boring
~The jokes remind me of the same type of self-referencial humor as expereinced with your first highschool GM
~The jokes still suck.
~The early game is a desperate struggle against keeping the squishies alive long enough for them to unleash the hurt on the enemies.
~The late game every fight is waiting on the wizard or equivilant to denign to cast the right spell after the rest of the party spend the whole combat setting it up.
~Enemies actually have some flavor to them that is easily apparent.
~Enemies are universially made tougher by merit of adding hitpoints and raw damage rather than tricks or tactics.

I wish the game had more elements of randomness, like miss chances based ona rolled die in combat rather than it only being effected on the map.

I'm marking this as a RECOMMEND, but only buy it if you really like old school RPGs and/or tabletop gaming

reviewText:
This game is based heavily on grinding, which I guess is par for the course for what was originally a phone title. Gotta sell those IAPs!

This would not be so bad if the game was actually free-to-play, or if the RPG mechanics were any good. After all, lots of titles in the genre have a bunch of grinding at their core and still manage to be fun.
Unfortunately, combat is shockingly shallow, character building and crafting might as well not be there, and while the quest structure is framed in an original/cute way, it just underlines how barebones everything is.

I was also put off by the shameless, constant nerd pandering -- which mostly takes the form of (you guessed it) lazy pop-culture references, but you also get healthy doses of terrible banter of course.

Not the most enjoyable way to waste your time, even if you can get it for cheap/free.

reviewText:
Heh.

-_-

Okay, so: do you A.) Like Dungeons and Dragons-style adventuring games?
B.) Like playing actual D&D style games, on pen and paper?
C.) Would like to try a simulator of the two?

This is that game.

Will you like it? That's debatable.

I bought this game when it was a daily deal because I like pen and paper D&D-style games. Note that I had received all of the boosts from the digital deluxe version.

The retro-style graphics are a nice aesthetic, and there is quite a bit of variety with the creatures you will encounter in the game.

So the game plays with you as the DM (dungeon master) overseeing a game of D20 Knights of Pen and Paper. You have seats that can sit how ever many characters you would like to use, but the last few seats require you to pay the in-game currency. You can keep grinding to afford the seats in the future.

For each seat, you can sit a type of character (ex: hipster, grandma) and assign them a specific class (ex: barbarian, bard). This offers a seemingly wide range of party configurations.

The difficulty is completely self-driven, as you are both the DM and the players. That being said, you may have an objective" to kill 5 orcs - you can choose to fight them 1-at-a-time
recommended: or whatever configuration you prefer. The entirety of the game involves A LOT of grinding
hoursPlayed: and this is even considering the boosts you may have gotten from the deluxe edition.\n\nI love D20 games
voteText: but this game can become repetitive extremely quickly. If there was a multiplayer cooperative functionality
helpfulPercent: it might have saved it a bit
votesHelpful: however
votesTotal: there isn't one.\n\nThere is A LOT of variety for you to upgrade - you can change everything from the type of table you're playing on (each type provides different bonuses) to the type of door in the room to the DM. All of this can help shape your overall party into a specfic area
commentsCount: or high MP
column16: magic-relying casters.\n\nI paid ~$5 US for the deluxe edition
column17: and I think even then you may want to hold off and wait for it to be cheaper
column18: if you are interested in trying the game."

reviewText:
This game is just absolutely fantastic! 20/D20

I've been wanting to get involved in D&D for AGES but I just can't seem to a) Find any friends who want too b) Find any groups in my area that run a weekly or something.. A little sad.. But oh well I'll keep looking. In the meantime - This game fills that space perfectly! It's got quick wit, great humor, reflections on a vast array of older games; most of which I had a really nice time remembering thanks to this beauty!

The gameplay is fairly quick and gets you into it without boring you in any way. A nice range of different classes, each one seperating it from the last meaning you can mix and match your 5-man squad quite a bit to your preferences!

Difficulty can be .. Sort off.. Scaled. By choosing more enemies it makes it more difficult. I personally don't class this as 'difficulty' as such, and you can cheat the system by setting the enemies closer or further apart to suit your teams attack.. Though, even with 7 enemies sometimes it can be 'easy'.. This is a slight downside, but still isn't much of one and you won't be choosing 7 enemies to fight until you become stronger anyway, as it is generally too much (when matched against similar levels that is).

But generally speaking this is a great game with tons of great moments!! If you're a fan of RPG's and D&D in general, you'll love this (I think..)!! :D

Plus the new ones out soon!! Can't wait!!!

reviewText:
Knights of Pen and Paper +1 wasn't really the game I was expecting to go through. I thought it was actually worse than it is, and I'm glad I ended up buying this title and playing through it's 9 hour-ish campaign. The basic premise is, you are a group of friends that are playing the much known fantasy tabletop role-playing game, and your adventures are depicted both through pixelated landscapes/characters and from what the D&D players are actually saying, or actually the dungeon master. Much like in the main idea from the movie Inception, you are playing a game in which the characters are playing a game. So, gameception?

KoP&P (Knights of Pen and Paper) is an RPG, and most features you expect from one are available in this title. Leveling up your characters, giving them new items, armor and weapons, upgrading your character's abilities, questing your way through until the very end, or until New Game +, in which your able to replay the whole game, with the same characters, but everything is harder. It didn't really attract me, since the main campaign features a bit of grinding and I didn't want to go through the same. It's useful for completing the achievements, though.

Soundtrack fits the theme of KoP&P, but can actually become boring after a few hours of gameplay. Another interesting feature is the abundance of references to tv shows, movies, etc. You eventually find a character named Nabe Gewell, which lives in Steam Island, which I found amusing. The 4th wall is also broken lots of times.

In conclusion, do yourself a favor, and purchase KoP&P. It entertained me for a couple hours and I'm sure it will do the same for you. Alas, if you actually don't enjoy D&D's concept, steer in the way of another game.

reviewText:
So the video preview is what got me to try this game. I will say it's the most meta RPG I've ever played and, unfortunately, it's very much in the spirit of a freemium facebook game.

You need gold to buy a cup to buy more party members. Need gold for party members. Food, Travel, so on, you need gold for quite a lot. But no worries, you can buy more gold for USD, just click the everpresent gold buy button in the top right.

I can see playing this game at short stretches, but I have no interest in the freemium nature of it.

reviewText: If you enjoy casual gaming, fantasy gaming, ever watched the D&D cartoon when you were a kid, ever played a tabletop book and dice RPG, or played any of the similar console or PC based titles and enjoyed them. Then there is likely no way you will not enjoy this game immensly. I am going to be picking up the DLC shortly. Don't pass on this delightful and light hearted title... You will not likely be disapointed.\n\nI have found no bugs, issues, glitches, or otherwise in this game. A well made, solid title. Enjoy...

reviewText:
Pretty brilliant. It's a turn based RPG, but it's not hard for noobies.
You can balance it yourself by starting with more or less characters. I would strongly recommend starting with 5 players because the endgame is very hard otherwise.

Other then that you really need to play it for an hour or two to find out if it's for you. I like the dry humor and pop culture references. And how it doesn't take itself too seriously. But some people call this 'lacking in depth' and I guess they're right too. They do re-use certain backgrounds and let you grind from level 32-37 and 1 mission later 37-45 at the end of the game, so they definitely rushed through the end trying to add some 'gameplay' without putting in work sadly. That level 50 mission is optional btw. Throughout the rest of the game there is rarely a need to grind though. Do note that the game has some large bugs. Some achievements are broken, some missions are broken, DLC doesn't work for some and there's graphical glitches. This seems like a hasty port honestly. And then there's the fact that if you want the Deluxier Edition you have to buy it at once. You can't upgrade. If you already have Normal edition or Deluxe edition (extra's, but no DLC) you're screwed. Also they just wiped everybody's saves trying to emplement the (not fully working) cloud save. Then wiped all saves again when reverting to the old build.

So the game is very fun, but beware that this game is published by Paradox. As long as you're lucky enough to be in the 90% for whom most things don't break you're good. But if something goes wrong there's no support and dealing with Paradox is like talking to a 3 year old and when they realize you're right they just ignore you.

I only recommend this game because it's unique. It's very money-grabby, too expensive and the publisher is unethical and clearly doesn't care about it's customers, but the game is so much  fun and most people don't care about what happens behind the scenes. And if I'd downvote it the fanboys would downvote this review and you wouldn't be reading about the downsides of this game right now.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pros:
The game is kind of humorous.
The backgrounds look nice.
They removed microtransactions

Cons:
The gameplay lacks any depth.
The game is super grindy.
The game is REALLY resource intensive for what it is. (It uses 14% to 17% of my CPU just idling at the title screen.)
Text is recycled far too often.
The music isn't bad, but it is way too short. So in a given fight it probably loops 5 or 6 times.
Alternate save files don't have independant gold, room items, characters, or classes; however, the blacksmith doesn't carry over. (The whole idea of all that being persistent is just stupid as it was physically impossible to get the game over achievement unless I deleted my save file.)
More of a nitpick, but the developers made themselves the best characters in the game. (That's a bit too narassistic, in my opinion, and since they have ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• one-liners it ruins most of the fun of the game.)


Overall:
I got the game in a sale because it looked like it would fun to play. Little did I know I would just make a party full of physical attackers, leave the twister floor mat on, and just run this in the background while I played other games. The game got a bit of a chuckle from me when I first played it, but as the game dragged on it just got more monotonous due to there being no real growth in the game. Everything in the game scales linearly, including mana costs, so it's more about playing keep up with how much health the enemies in later areas have as opposed to actually feeling strong.

reviewText:
This is a really fun game.

PROS- Nice pixelart with plenty of eastereggs in each scene, A funny story with even more references littered throughout, A solid soundtrack, A solid comabt system with clear meanings for every stat, A variety of classes and upgrades for different playstyles and differing playthroughs.

CONS- You are going to have to grind quite a bit, the difficulty curve could use some rebalancing for early game to require less grinding.

NEUTRAL- There are microstransactions in the game for gold. They are NOT required in any way though for the actual game. They act as time savers allowing you to buy better items and xp potions faster. You will likely make enough gold just playing the game anyways.

reviewText:
At first, I thought this game was great!  However, then it just turned into a grind and the completionist in me forced me to play through and finish it.  Here are the main complaints:

-The game progresses pretty smoothly and you don't need to grind much until the last dungeon.  I could get to the last dungeon easily, but then had to do almost 5 levels of grinding with all my guys just to be able to complete the final dungeon.
-The blacksmith levels up far too slowly. The only way to level him is to get him grindstones, which you can find 1 to 4 of in certain locations.  However, at the final level you can give him 20-30 grindstones and barely move his xp bar.
-Any game that encourages micro-transactions has already failed.

reviewText:
This game is a wonderful mini-masterpiece that makes you feel as if you're playing a table-top game without the actual table or friends. You can experience D&D-style gameplay without having to break out dice, charts, pencils, and painted figures, and it really makes it much easier to immerse yourself into the game. With the deluxe edition, you get SO many awesome new items and references to play with, including furniture such as THE TARDIS from Doctor Who, 800 gold coins and starting buff items, and even a new player character that makes a powerful magic user! I'd honestly buy the game just for that.

So many different players-class combinations to choose from that could either make the game difficult or easy, and it's so much fun to try different combos!
I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes RPG games, humor, and gaming/television references!

reviewText:
8Bit graphics and 8Bit sound. Brings you right back to the old school feel. There is even the added humor in the game of the players questions and quips.

I did enjoy the game and its not a bad little game but I wouldn't pay more then $1.50 for it.

The game seems to be built on micro transactions where you need to buy gold to get some uber items, purchase trinkets to get the option to fill up the other three chairs.

You start off with selecting 2 players for the game and have to spend 10gold to open a third spot and more top open the rest, allot more.

I kinda like it but its a Facebook game that found its way onto Steam. It would be better enjoyed on the iPad then on the PC.

reviewText:
This is quite possibly one of the more interesting games I've played in the past couple years and mind you I own 400+ games because it takes the classic Dungeons and Dragons board game and turns it into a sprite game while poking fun at the fact its all essentially imaginary and your characters make some funny comments now and then out of character lol.

Overall the its a very well rounded game and I definately can't stop playing it.


I'd say the only thing that is a negative point about the game is that to upgrade your gear you need to level up the blacksmith by collecting a literal f'ing s**t ton of an item called a Grindstone which to get them you buy them from the shop(waste of money) or mine them which takes f'ing forever. I found an exploit though that makes it easier to double the amount of grindstones you get. When you start the game to the east of the starting town is a cave where you can mine grindstones. When you click on one and the dice rolls up you need 6 or higher to get the grindstone. The key here is after clicking on the ore deposit just start pressing spacebar because once the dice stops rolling and you do or don't get the grindstone the act of pressing spacebar triggers the dice to reroll giving you another chance to get a grindstone. I went from getting around 10 grindstones every minute to around 20-25 grindstones in the same amount of time.

reviewText: This little game, a nostalgic blend of retro-console RPG's and old-school D&D, is novel and amusing. I love the interface, with the DM seated on one side of a table and the players (characters) on the other side, and with the scenery changing around them and the ranks of opponents springing up from behind the DM's shoulders. Character development and turn-based combat are simplistic and two-dimensional, but interesting and challenging. However, it all starts to get repetitive and a little monotonous after a half-dozen or so hours of play. If you can get this game on sale for under $5, it's worthwhile. As for the in-game gold that can be bought with real-world money: It's totally unnecessary, and buying some may even spoil the game for you, since it will make the game too easy and reduce the number of enjoyable hours you'll get out of it.

reviewText: So I've spent the last 5 hours playing this, and I think its well worth the $3.74 for the deluxe version. I bought it on today's daily deal, then sent one to my husband as well. He's a long time D&D nerd and I've played on occassion as well.\n\nI'm only around levels 19-24 in my characters and spent most of my inital gold opening up full party options and some table add-ons, so I've been doing a lot of dungeon crawling to earn money for armor/weapons upgrades. There is an option to buy gold with real money, but I'm finding it easy to earn the gold I need so it's really just a time saver, and the cash shop is not quite the money-grab a lot of other cash shops are.

I too have been thoroughly enjoying the game and it's a shame those MicroTransaction (MT) haters can't see past their own hate of MTs to give this game a go. The MTs are such a non-issue, the game is not gimped in any way, shape or form without using the MTs. All I can say is, give the game a go.. you will genuine like it if you like old school rpgs.

One of the most enjoyable turn based RPGs I've played for a while.

reviewText:
Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition is a strange little game that takes the fourth wall and breaks it. It doesn't just take a sledgehammer to it or anything, it demolishes that wall and lets you view a weird (but amusing) hybrid of a pen-and-paper RPG with the characters as well.

Visually the game manages to hold it's unique touch, even on the PC platform. Music also does fairly well at making itself memorable in terms of it's melody but to some it could get extremely repetitive over time.

While this game does have an in-game-store with which you can buy gold" (the game's currency for getting buffs and permanent benefits
date: but the gold is just as easily earned by playing making the in-game-store a bit useless except to those who are extremely impatient.\n\nThe game can be a great time waster for people wanting to poke a little fun at the D&D genre and has taken a good number of hours from me. Without the timed waits that the mobile version has
recommended: this is a much better build that just lets you play without interference."
hoursPlayed: August 6, 2013
voteText: true

reviewText: I feel torn about this game.  At first it was interesting in the simplicity and style, yet as the game progresses it feel immensely tedious.  There will be quests where you are required to go from one location to another and have to fight at each step along the way, sometimes up to five or six battles.  Then once you arrive the quest is to slay a number of monsters repeatedly.  The endgame seems almost unfair, requiring a lot of grinding unless you spend a lot of time exploring sidequests.  Based on the price, I think the game has a niche in the category of game where you advance through it periodically while taking a break from other games.  Could improvements be made? Absolutely, but for an indie title with some creative 4th wall shattering, it serves it's place decently.

reviewText: Despite being sprites rather than 3D, this game threatened to overheat my laptop, which I count the first strike against it. It's no good sacrificing graphics quality if you're still going to demand huge amounts of GPU investment. The second strike is that the massive amounts of heat are going to waste doing nothing at high speeds - the game is irritatingly slow at times, and I used CheatEngine to double KPP+1's speed to get it to a tolerable level. In-app purchases are the third strike leading me to conclude: KPP+1 is a bad game. Cute characters, witty humor, and a whole lot of hack'n'slash against evil monsters doesn't make up for poor underlying design.

reviewText:
What a little gem!

I found this beauty in the Paradox Humble Bundle (still available at the time of writing so go grab it if you haven't already) and fell in love with it. Not the style of RPG that I've really had much experience with so for me this was a bit of an experiment. I digress, a simple and smooth game that's easy to get into. I found it a little odd that my rogue has an attack almost double that of my warrior but that's pretty much the only issue I've had. Of course there's grinding... and then some more grinding

Oh I'm sorry did you think you were done? Guess what!?

MORE GRINDING

But that's what you sign up for with these games, you have to be prepared for it and I have to say, it pays off. The parody of the traditional D&D scenario is wonderful and the humor is very self aware. The references are tasteful and abundant but not overly so that they obscure the story.

I would recommend this to anyone lacking the means, friends or who's simply as antisocial as myself to actually play D&D (not a bad thing) to give this a go if you are interested in that sort of thing.

reviewText:
This game is awesome, well worth the low price, I also recommend the digital deluxe edition. It includes some gold and stuff, but mainly a village thats GREAT for grinding xp in the early parts of the game.
Anyway, heres my thoughts:
Sound: The soundtrack isn't bad, pretty much what you'd expect in an rpg game, I do occasionally get sick of the looping song. However, the boss music is awesome and intense.
Graphics: The graphics rock, It's all pixel art and it looks awesome!
Gameplay: The gameplay is pretty simple, but its also fun and at times, hilarious. The basic idea is your a bunch of people playing a game like dungeons and dragons in a basement. You choose your characters race (Pizza guy, jock, nerd etc) and class (cleric warrior paladin mage etc) and start playing. As you level up you will unlock and upgrade your different skills. There are plenty of fun items to find and equip, and I also joy at leveling up. Not only can you  buy ingame items, you can buy furniture, new tables, and snacks and drinks for the basement that your ACTUALLY playing the game in for buffs in the game. Pretty funny if you ask me. The game is very fun to play overall, even though at times, the missions feel a bit similar.
Overall I would give this game a 8.7 out of 10.

reviewText:
It's a charming concept that loses its charm fairly quickly. The humor gets old, and the combat system gets boring and repetitive. The story is pretty bland and its execution is poor, drowned in the midst of required jobber battles that the game throws at you in a mockery of typical poor DMing style. It's got the American Nightmare problem in which it acknowledges why what it's parodying is lame, but doesn't actually do anything to fix it. Something that's ironically bad is still, unfortunately, bad.

In all, it feels like a quirky, above-average quickie mobile game that sells itself as an engaging RPG.

If you like that sort of thing, then get it when it's on sale. It's not worth $10.

reviewText:
As a 25+ year veteran of pen and paper gaming in real life it was hard not to instantly fall in love with this game when I was put on to it for my tablet, when I saw it was on Steam I just had to have it here as well, the Deluxer content is somewhat useful but by no means essential but I'm happy to put the money towards the company in the hopes of continuing the title.
The game captured the feel of a well run gaming group with a very tongue in cheek look at the genre and while it is easy to offend such minority interests it is hard to endear, and this game certainly doesn't offend :)
The pop culture references date from my childhood to modern day and any nerd/geek will find something in there they relate to from their childhood, very well written and humorous throughout.
Game play is easy and as I like to call it, drunk friendly, easy enough to play while intoxicated, engrossing enough not to get dull.
In my opinion this is the best game I've played after Skyrim and Fallout 3 and if you know me that is a high recommendation indeed.
Behold studios are my 8 bit Bethesda
All in all you will not regret buying this game and once you play it you'll be recommending it too.

reviewText: It's not often that after only an hour of gameplay I don't feel the need to press on. The graphics are cute and the game sounds nice, but the gameplay and story are just not where they need to be. Yeah, the idea of playing a computer RPG about Pen & Paper RPGs is a cute idea, but the game is so damn meta that it actually feels like an amateur effort. Prepare to fight rats, goblins and evil wizards. Yawn. The character creation system looks very detailed at first, but then you realize that of the six initial classes, most only have 3 active skills and one passive skill for the ENTIRE game, and one or two have - gasp - FOUR skills. Here's every encounter in the game: rogue/mage use stuns, paladin use taunt, cleric heal, then attack, attack, attack, attack... Leveling up consists of upgrading one of your four skills, and weapons/armor upgrades require extreme grinding to level up your blacksmith to get a CHANCE at getting a straight upgrade. Oh and what's this? MICROTRANSACTIONS? In a game I already paid for? Even as a casual RPG, I would avoid getting this game at any price point. On a tablet? Maybe. On PC there are just way too many better indie titles at the same price point.

The game captured the feel of a well run gaming group with a very tongue in cheek look at the genre and while it is easy to offend such minority interests it is hard to endear, and this game certainly doesn't offend :)
The pop culture references date from my childhood to modern day and any nerd/geek will find something in there they relate to from their childhood, very well written and humorous throughout.
Game play is easy and as I like to call it, drunk friendly, easy enough to play while intoxicated, engrossing enough not to get dull.
In my opinion this is the best game I've played after Skyrim and Fallout 3 and if you know me that is a high recommendation indeed.
Behold studios are my 8 bit Bethesda
All in all you will not regret buying this game and once you play it you'll be recommending it too.

reviewText:
This game is awesome, well worth the low price, I also recommend the digital deluxe edition. It includes some gold and stuff, but mainly a village thats GREAT for grinding xp in the early parts of the game.
Anyway, heres my thoughts:
Sound: The soundtrack isn't bad, pretty much what you'd expect in an rpg game, I do occasionally get sick of the looping song. However, the boss music is awesome and intense.
Graphics: The graphics rock, It's all pixel art and it looks awesome!
Gameplay: The gameplay is pretty simple, but its also fun and at times, hilarious. The basic idea is your a bunch of people playing a game like dungeons and dragons in a basement. You choose your characters race (Pizza guy, jock, nerd etc) and class (cleric warrior paladin mage etc) and start playing. As you level up you will unlock and upgrade your different skills. There are plenty of fun items to find and equip, and I also joy at leveling up. Not only can you  buy ingame items, you can buy furniture, new tables, and snacks and drinks for the basement that your ACTUALLY playing the game in for buffs in the game. Pretty funny if you ask me. The game is very fun to play overall, even though at times, the missions feel a bit similar.
Overall I would give this game a 8.7 out of 10.

reviewText: It's not often that after only an hour of gameplay I don't feel the need to press on. The graphics are cute and the game sounds nice, but the gameplay and story are just not where they need to be. Yeah, the idea of playing a computer RPG about Pen & Paper RPGs is a cute idea, but the game is so damn meta that it actually feels like an amateur effort. Prepare to fight rats, goblins and evil wizards. Yawn. The character creation system looks very detailed at first, but then you realize that of the six initial classes, most only have 3 active skills and one passive skill for the ENTIRE game, and one or two have - gasp - FOUR skills. Here's every encounter in the game: rogue/mage use stuns, paladin use taunt, cleric heal, then attack, attack, attack, attack... Leveling up consists of upgrading one of your four skills, and weapons/armor upgrades require extreme grinding to level up your blacksmith to get a CHANCE at getting a straight upgrade. Oh and what's this? MICROTRANSACTIONS? In a game I already paid for? Even as a casual RPG, I would avoid getting this game at any price point. On a tablet? Maybe. On PC there are just way too many better indie titles at the same price point.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game, I really did. It had a nice aesthetic, nice music, and it was from a small studio. Had I been aware that this was an iOS app before it was a PC game, I might've been more wary. The first couple hours went by relatively nicely, but after that, not so much.

If you buy the Deluxe Edition DLC, you get the Magika Wizard, a character with a better passive skill advantage than most other (see next point) characters. Around level 15, you unlock the Developer Player Characters, self-inserts that have even better passives, making whatever current party you're using seem feeble in comparison.

Also around this time, you'll notice your strength isn't getting you as far as it did in the beginning, so you go to buy gear. Only, the blacksmith, by default, has a 30-some percent chance at actually crafting the item you pay him for. So, either you toss bags of money at the him, praying that he succeeds (because of course he doesn't reimburse you), or you get grindstones, items that let you level him up". It takes around 2000 grindstones at 25 gold apiece to have him reach 100%. That's 50
hoursPlayed: but what's this? You can buy gold in-game for real money! Of course you can. Sadly
voteText: this game really was designed as a cash-hungry iOS game first and foremost. 4/10

reviewText:
Firstly I will tell you this game is a mobile port.Second it has a microtransaction of buying ingame gold for cash,but you never  and I mean never need to use it.There are plenty of items ingame that increase the amount of gold you get dropped that have other stats to them.Now to the review.

Short Review:
Game has classes you can swap in and out,skills that you can level individually,upgradeable class locked weapons/armor and plenty of item accessories and consumables.The game has pop culture reference comedy all throughout it,hardly any variation in quest types and is grindy since you only turn-base fight your way through each situation for the most part.Plenty of boss fights in the game,no puzzles, and a small learning curve on how to handle things. Uses dice roll to determine things such as crafting chance,battles,etc.

If you like games you can play 5min-1hr + at a time,do not mind grind , a pop culture heavy comedic story, and little varation in gameplay then pick it up on sale, or in a bundle. I would not pay full price,just does not feel like a $10 game , more like a $2.50-$5 one.

Regular Review:
The game itself is a comedic sort of table top dice roll turned into a video game.The dialog trees,characters, and the story have comedy all throughout them. The game has tons of pop culture references from 1970s- onward in both enemies,outfits and dialog.

Gameplay mechanic wise you pretty much fight turn based fight your way through all the quests you do.There is hardly any variation in the quests escort,item fetch/deliever,rescue, and fight/slay. They incorporate you grind fighting your way through.There are no puzzles or anything so do not expect much outsite of witty dialog and fights.

Items in the game are what you would expect, consumables with stat buffs that last for a certain time.Weapons/armor are not sold but are upgraded by blacksmiths.They are only found in towns as well as item purchases.There are different character classes each with 4 skills that you can level up individually.When you decide what character classes you want you have to pick a person whom hs their on special stat they add to be that class.You can swap in and out character classes that you level up when you are at towns with taverns.

The game can be played for 5min- 1hr+ depending on how much grinding and story you are willing to play through. There is a NG+ when you beat the game to continue on your adventures which resets all the quests making the mobs tougher at the beginning onward.

My final verdict on this game is if you do not mind the grind,it is a enjoyable title.Its simple yet to the point.I played it in spurts and had fun playing it.Its deffinately not for everyone but no game out there is.Get it on sale or in a bundle, not worth $10 to me more like $2.50-$5 game.Not for lack of content,more for lack of variations in quests and gameplay mechanics.

reviewText:
First game I've ever bought on Steam where I've not actually gotten what I paid for. Sure sometimes a game will have bugs, and sometimes there may be un-noticed system requirements/limitations which are my fault for missing. But here, it's not even the right product. Advertised as win/mac/linux, but buying the deluxe version, none of that extra content shows up for linux. No response from the publisher/devs on their own steam forum linux-specific discussion. First time I've ever felt truly cheated on Steam.


Edit: Dec 12th, 2014
WIth the latest update, it seems that at long last 2 1/2 months later, the Deluxe Version finally works under linux. Of course they've still been selling for Linux this whole time instead of taking that off until it was fixed. What miniscule communication there has been in that time was all of poor quality and incorrect. Moreover this actual fix wasn't even described or announced. Still cannot recommend.

I would not recommend this game to anyone. Seriously, do not buy it, its repetetive poorly presentated garbage.

reviewText:
This beings back so many great memories of playing the original table top Dungeons and Dragons. I have only put in a few hours but for being an old school gamer, this game is what I was hoping it would be, fun and attention grabbing. You start out with 2 characters and you start doing quest, mostly by killing mosters, which you gain XP and coins. With the coins you can unlock more characters, buy equipment, pay for travel, buy additional tables, buy bonuses, etc. If you are bored easy, do not like 8-bit graphics, never played D&D, or do not want to grind out some levels, then this game might not be for you.

Pros:

-Adjustable screen resolution
-Like you are playing a D&D game
-Replayable

Cons:

-Music (8-bit music but mute works great)
-Grindy

reviewText:
Cute game, but needlessly difficult.

My game functionally ended when enough of my party died that I couldn't reliably fight and didn't have enough cash to resurrect anyone.  Could I have farmed for the money in low level fights?  Yes.  Was that prospect enjoyable?  Not in the least.

I do enjoy that while the game has some pretty standard stereotypes of gamers, it also embraces women, jocks, and businessmen, amongst others, at the table.

All the geek culture shout-outs were amusing.

Still, any game I can't finish isn't a game I'm going to recommend.

Get this guys: Single-player Earthbound / Mother style graphics transformed into a board game. You get to choose your events and your own spawned monsters since you take the role as a player and a GM at the same time.

The +1 expansions makes the game worth playing. But the Blacksmith is very unforgiving. 40% success rate as a base to upgrade your items. \n
The control scheme makes it ideal for touch tablet/touch screen users, but if you don't mind moving your mouse around and clicking a lot. GET A BIT OF THAT OSU WORKOUT!... Then you should be fine.

I got it on a daily deal for 60% off. It's worth it big time for that.
But when it's not on sale and it's 10 dollars? 15 dollars? What... WHATTTTTTTT!?

What slightly made me frown were two things: A) Their Android/iPhone App Version costs $2.99. B) There is the option to buy more gold with Microtransactions (convenience, they say.) While the only thing you can buy is currency, it really makes most users very discouraged to buy it. But trust me, it's a lot better to play it at a normal rate. You'll grow to love your characters more.

Given that some builds are worth more than others, you'll see that all the passives are worth leveling a lot in the early levels. There are unlockable classes, and loot to gather. The start of the game gets very slow, but hey. This game's a neat RPG to burn your time. While exponentially better for touch users, it's a neat little gem to stumble upon. BUT WHATEVER YOU DO, DO NOT PRESS THAT +" SIGN ON THE TOP RIGHT CORNER.

Play the game for what it is."
