reviewText:
Boring.
Knights of Pen & Paper is long, dull, grindy and most of all it is boring.
It starts out novel enough. You are playing a game about a bunch of gamers playing D&D
A few obvious jokes and references and things start out pretty well.
The sound, music, graphics, they all lend themselves pretty well.
But the grind, jeez! This is a single player game! Who thought that...
Converted mobile app with a cash shop in the mobile version? Ooooooooooooooooh

I don't need to say much more really. As far as converted mobile games go its actually really well ported. But the play time is so artifically padded that you probably will not complete the game.
A sequel has been announced and I hope and pray it addresses the flaws this game has or even just does away with the excessive grinding for the inevitable PC port.

I know some smartass will reply that this is an RPG and you are supposed to grind but this isn't 1997 anymore. Games like Bravely Default, like Magic Fantasy Battle 4, have come along and said 'listen, there is grinding but we streamlined it or we made it fun.'

I stopped caring about the storyline the 8th time I was told to backtrack for excuse reasons. I especially stopped caring when my Lv32 Barbarian, with maxed equipment, wearing 4 +9attack items, still can't one shot a friggen spider!
I especially was agitated that a newer version of this game was released that I can't simply upgrade too, or even buy apprently since steam says 'you already own that game' when clearly I don't.

Flaws aside the game is enjoyable in short bursts which is fitting given its mobile phone roots. It was ported to the PC and no real effort was made to make it a more PC friendly game. Instead its dull, repetitive and boring.
Also the achievement, beat in 365 (game)days, is unachievable it seems. That's always nice for the achievement hunters.

reviewText: Quite an addicting little game. Tne story involves a group of good ol' table-top rpg players trying to define the thin line that separates the game fro reality. It is a turn-based RPG where you choose what kind of adventurers you want in your group and level their character sheets as you would in a traditional table-top RPG, with dice rolls and everything. The story is the main selling point of the game and it does have its' own little charm to it, I did laugh at most of the jokes, though some of them fall a bit flat (it is mostly reference-based humour). There's a lot of text to go through, so it is not recommended for people who like to skip most of the dialogue in games. Good for playing if you have a bit of time on your hands, however I would not recommend it for hardcore" players - they might be disappointed with the combat system (which is a bit simplistic and does not involve a lot of management) and find the game too repetitive. The progress does feel rewarding
recommended: there is quite a high level of grinding involved which should be taken into consideration. The art style and character design match the tone of the game well and the simple animation feels natural. The music could be better
hoursPlayed: after some time it can get a bit repetitive.\nOverall - I do like the game and I do recommend it if you are just looking for a little time waster."

reviewText: Everything good about retro RPG video games as well as classic pen and paper like Dungeons & Dragons is mixed into one wonderful experience in the form of Knights of Pen and Paper. In the game, you play as a group of friends, getting together to play Dungeons & Dragons. You're not just picking classes, but picking which real life" person is playing the characters in game. Want grandma to be the paladin on your team? No problem! Think your little brother would be best suited as a stealthy rogue? You can do that too. Although the character creation is as simple as matching an archetype to a class (like Hipster Mage or Pizza Guy Druid)
date: it's pretty fun and gives the game replayability as you want to experiment with different combinations.\n\nThe storyline is light
recommended: but definitely will bring back memories to anyone who has played Dungeons & Dragons in their lives. You travel through towns like "Journey Village" and battle monsters to save missing kings in a world full of pop culture references. It might be a bit silly if you're looking for a serious RPG
hoursPlayed: but if you love the classic turn-based battle style of the early Final Fantasy games
voteText: you'll at least appreciate the simple awesomeness of the gameplay. It's also hugely accessible and easy to learn for those who've never played that kinda game before.\n\nYou'll get the most out of this if you're just a huge RPG fan
helpfulPercent: because Knights of Pen and Paper relies a lot on nostalgia. Still
votesHelpful: it's a really fun RPG that can eat up many hours of your life in a very satisfying way. It's a really good example of what indie game companies are capable of. Oh
votesTotal: and if you complain about the graphics
votesFunny: I have a fist to shake at you."

reviewText: Fantastic game; totally worth buy at the discount. Its basically a parody d&d 8/16bit game. reviewText:
KoPP is modeled after D&D gameplay. You play as a group of roleplayers sitting around a table, going on an adventure led by a dungeon master. No, really. The DM is actually there, narrating the quest. It‚Äôs a really unique RPG in its presentation, though not so much in its gameplay, which is a rather simple turn-based battle system.

The simplicity owes to the game's origins on mobile platforms, and this is why recommending KoPP is complicated for me: It still plays exactly like a mobile game, much better suited for playing in small intervals. Understandably, a lot of people don't expect that from a $10 PC game. If it was the same price as the mobile version ($3), maybe it could get away with its lack of depth. Not for this price.

It's also worth noting that there are microtransactions in the game. [Update: Not anymore. As of patch 2.09 (2014/02/14), they have been removed from the game.]. Also, some achievements are broken, and won't be fixed for a while. [Update: Also fixed in patch 2.09, I was able to obtain all of them.]

You may be wondering why I recommend the game after all. Very simple. I still enjoyed it. I'd play it while watching a stream or something, when I wanted to unwind and avoid ultra-complex games. In a way, I went through it with the mobile mindset, and this is the case in which I'd recommend KoPP, if you want a simple game.

Just don't get it for full price, even if you really want it. It's not worth it. Wait for a sale of at least 50% off.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you like turn-based fantasy combat and have nostalgia for tabletop RPGs, this just might be the game for you!

Gameplay can be a bit repetitive, so it's not really a game you can sit and play for six hours, but but half an hour here, two hours there? It's lovely! And there are some interesting story turns I've encountered so far.

Mostly I love it because it's not too serious, not too involved, perfect for a short gaming session, and has a great sense of humor. Perfect for when I've got a bit of time to kill. Tough battles can also require some careful thought or you'll find your party dead! And it's great how you can adjust the battles yourself, decide how tough it'll be, and challenge yourself as much as you like. Lot of customization in the gaming experience.

Plus, so many things to buy in the shops and so many items to find!

Seriously, I love the game.

reviewText: SO GOOD. reviewText:
KoPP is modeled after D&D gameplay. You play as a group of roleplayers sitting around a table, going on an adventure led by a dungeon master. No, really. The DM is actually there, narrating the quest. It‚Äôs a really unique RPG in its presentation, though not so much in its gameplay, which is a rather simple turn-based battle system.

The simplicity owes to the game's origins on mobile platforms, and this is why recommending KoPP is complicated for me: It still plays exactly like a mobile game, much better suited for playing in small intervals. Understandably, a lot of people don't expect that from a $10 PC game. If it was the same price as the mobile version ($3), maybe it could get away with its lack of depth. Not for this price.

It's also worth noting that there are microtransactions in the game. [Update: Not anymore. As of patch 2.09 (2014/02/14), they have been removed from the game.]. Also, some achievements are broken, and won't be fixed for a while. [Update: Also fixed in patch 2.09, I was able to obtain all of them.]

You may be wondering why I recommend the game after all. Very simple. I still enjoyed it. I'd play it while watching a stream or something, when I wanted to unwind and avoid ultra-complex games. In a way, I went through it with the mobile mindset, and this is the case in which I'd recommend KoPP, if you want a simple game.

Just don't get it for full price, even if you really want it. It's not worth it. Wait for a sale of at least 50% off.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you like turn-based fantasy combat and have nostalgia for tabletop RPGs, this just might be the game for you!

Gameplay can be a bit repetitive, so it's not really a game you can sit and play for six hours, but but half an hour here, two hours there? It's lovely! And there are some interesting story turns I've encountered so far.

Mostly I love it because it's not too serious, not too involved, perfect for a short gaming session, and has a great sense of humor. Perfect for when I've got a bit of time to kill. Tough battles can also require some careful thought or you'll find your party dead! And it's great how you can adjust the battles yourself, decide how tough it'll be, and challenge yourself as much as you like. Lot of customization in the gaming experience.

Plus, so many things to buy in the shops and so many items to find!

Seriously, I love the game.

reviewText:
Knights of Pen and Paper +1 brings back memories of poorly lit basements and sitting on steel folding chairs next to a double set of card tables. Cans of Mountain Dew strewn about the floor from exciting fights and pulling out the natural 20 when you needed it.

KPP+1 contains all the tabletop RPG elements with a highly customizable experience. You can select from several people for your PCs, You can unlock more people within the game as well as unlock more classes to play after completing adventure paths. The feature of the game that keeps me playing is the location changes. You start by sitting in a basement. Starting the game changes the surroundings and you are transported to a town, field, or cave!

The culture references are plentiful and will make any geek giggle and say No Way!" a few times. I've counted over 20 references so far and I'm pretty sure I haven't found them all.

A few people seem upset about the microstransactions. That is completely optional. You can earn gold in the game. It will take you a while longer
date: but buying gold isn't required.\n\nI'd buy this game for any geek I know
recommended: probably even the deluxe edition for those I know who would appreciate it."

reviewText:
Looking for a game that you can pick up or leave on the fly? Then this is it. think of it as an actual pen and paper game like Dungeons and Dragons. then sprinkle in the NES Final Fantasy graphics and battle system and there you go you have this game.

The battles are pretty quick, and you can save in the middle of things making it nice to come back to.

Nice features to the game are the power ups you can purchase for your room that offer bonuses to your team, like extra gold when you defeat foes or extra Xp (the power ups are like pictures on the wall or snacks on the table).  I also liked that the game size was pretty small  around 100mb, which means I can leave it on my computer  for when I want a quick game.  I definitly suggest getting the +1 edition  since it offers a few extras that you can not get  on the  normal version.

reviewText:
Do you like Dungeons and Dragons? Do you like turn-based RPGs? Pixel-art? Yes?
This is your game.
This is a great D&D style RPG without the faux real-time of Baldur's Gate and Dragon Age: Origins
It is a very simple game, but thats what makes it so easy to pick up in play.
Not to mention that you can also controll the Dungeon Master(Narrator) which makes the game more or less challenging depending on your play style. (Although fighting low-level enemies gives you low-level rewards)
The game also has a very nice Pixel-art style that is not only beautiful to look at but nice to play through. The music is also one of the best parts of the game, with a pixelated style that reminds me of old-school western RPG with a battle theme as addictive as that of any Final Fantasy game.
Overall this is probably the most genuine fun I've had with an RPG in a long time, and easily one of my best finds/purchases.

reviewText:
Tabletop rping gone meta. This game is chock full of little gags, from visual ones in the background to quotes and characters. The gameplay itself is solid and is a lot of fun. There are times where you do have to grind but that's standard issue for an rpg and if you dislike that then there are very few rpg's I would or could recommend.

I have no issues with this game... With one exception, the in game microtransactions. You can avoid them quite easily, but it irks me that it is still included in a game I had to pay for in the first place. Either be free and have microtransactions or paid and not have them not paid and have them, that's just underhanded. That being said it's actually really easy to get around. If your main team dies just create a new one and any coins they earn will be shared between the different playthroughs.

There's also a new game + mode but it doesn't really add anything except the monsters being more difficult.

I would highly recommend this game but I would also wait for it to appear in a steam sale.

reviewText:
This game has a lot of charm and I enjoyed my two play-throughs. However it boils down to very shallow RPG that's comparable to some of the original GameBoy's launch titles.

You select a premade character, there's no way to customize their look but you do get to distribute points to their character sheets. Each of the 10 classes only has 4 abilities, and that is counting their passives. Damage is either magical or physical, no breakdowns within such as fire, slashing, holy, etc.  You'll quickly find others to join your party and unlock new classes to choose from.

An interesting feature is that when a battle starts you choose what type of enemies appear and how many there are, you're the dungeon master as well as the player. You'll probably want to have a tank in your party to taunt, and at least one area of effect damage dealer, along with a healer, and maybe a single target damager to mop up the rough edges and elites. Extremely basic tactics here.

The unlockables were nice (they were previously microtransactions but changed in this mobile to Steam port to be bought only with in game gold), but they make the game far too easy. Even with the cheats off don't expect a challege here. But you'll probably get some laughs and have fun, especially if you've ever put hours into any RPG. This one won't try to keep you for long and it's cheap.

reviewText: SO GOOD. If you play D&D, if you play RPGs, and are not averse to casual-tier play, this is an excellent pick,\nThe class/race combinations allow some basic entry-level optimizing, as does skill advancement. The loot pool is doesn't really have strong variety; there's a few weak over-specialized items and a few strong general stats-on-stats items. But, the storyline is entertaining in a quirky way as is the dialog. There isn't a lot of grinding, you can level quickly via the quest line if you play well. I consider KoPnP+1 one of the safest bets for your money.

reviewText: Surprisingly addictive.  A very original idea--playing both the game master and the players of a pen-and-paper RPG within the context of a computer game--that actually works very very well.  The graphics are retro but appealing, as is the music.  The story does not take itself seriously at all, but this is a good thing, as it makes for some very fun casual gameplay and a lot more content and play time than I expected.

reviewText: It's not a bad little game.  It's a port/adaptation of a game originally developed for smart devices, but it plays quite well in translation. There are a few small design changes I'd have made differently, and it's not as funny as I had expected, but it's a neat turn-based RPG done simply with a couple cool extras that provide some depth and customization. My overall impression after about ten hours would be a solid 8/10.  I don't feel the need to seek out a RL game of D&D afer playing this, but at least I can dork out over a D20 in secret thanks to Knights of Pen and Paper.

reviewText:
Knights of Pen and Paper +1, is... Different.

Something you should know:
On the google play store, it is only ¬£1.99.
On steam it is ¬£7.99. For the SAME GAME.
Just for this, I wouldn't reccommend buying it from Steam on principle, as even though it is a brillian game, it is still only a mobile android app. On PC.
Now I got this game with a Humble Bundle, so assuming I paid the ¬£1.99 for it, I can certainly say it was worth it.

I think my first runthrough took approx 12 hours, that wasn't rushed but it wasn't lazed either, so even if you where to pay ¬£7.99, it still has more play time then most ¬£40 hit title campaigns.

In the game you take control of 5 people role playing in a board RPG pretty much, and without going into to much detail, it's like playing a game of Dungeons & Dragons with amusing characters and dungeonmaster.
The missions are reasonably simple, and if you complete the entire campaign in a day, like me, then it does get somewhat repetitive by the end, though if you actually have a life and pace it out a bit more, you may not find this the same.

The game is FULL of references, there are pointers to Star Wars, Pokemon, Sponge Bob Square Pants, TMNT, Final Fantasy, Mario and much much more, almost every five minutes I would see something and be amazed at how many references they have fit in there.

That is everything, and if you are reading this and the Humble Bundle PC & Android Bundle 9 is still on (It is until 14/04/14) then go and get it, as it is worth it.

reviewText:
Tabletop rping gone meta. This game is chock full of little gags, from visual ones in the background to quotes and characters. The gameplay itself is solid and is a lot of fun. There are times where you do have to grind but that's standard issue for an rpg and if you dislike that then there are very few rpg's I would or could recommend.

I have no issues with this game... With one exception, the in game microtransactions. You can avoid them quite easily, but it irks me that it is still included in a game I had to pay for in the first place. Either be free and have microtransactions or paid and not have them not paid and have them, that's just underhanded. That being said it's actually really easy to get around. If your main team dies just create a new one and any coins they earn will be shared between the different playthroughs.

There's also a new game + mode but it doesn't really add anything except the monsters being more difficult.

I would highly recommend this game but I would also wait for it to appear in a steam sale.

reviewText:
Hard to recommend, but recommending nonetheless. Why? It's just full of charm, funny little cultural references and has a pretty good amount of content. However combat gets very boring as each class has 4 abilities, one of which is just a passive for 80-90% of the classes. So you largely spam the same 1-2 abilities, with the rare use (sometimes once a fight later on) of a 3rd ability, and sometimes a basic attack.

Other gripe is upgrading items at the blacksmith. Farming grindstones takes forever after the 1st or 2nd upgrade for him. However if you want upgrades without spending ALL of your gold, you need to gather dozens of these at a time for a 5-10% increase in chance of succesfully forging an item. Don't even bother trying unless you're at about 60% success, because you can waste almost all your gold upgrading one or two items. It's a shame because this could have been a really fun and important mechanic, but feels really forced. The only way to get grindstones is travel to caves, and hopefully roll a high enough number for each ore vein present, or spend 25 G a piece. As I said though this can take ALOT of grindstones and buying that amount can really add up in early-midgame as gold generally isnt earned fast. Battles (depending on bonuses of items you have and what you are fighting) generally drop 1-20 gold.

The blacksmith, repetive fighting and slow accumlation of gold are painfully dull or even annoying. However, the concept, dialogue, references, simplicity and music keep it entertaining enough to play for 20 or so minutes at a time.

reviewText: This game is one of those games that is hella fun until you realize that the first couple hours which were so awesome are what you're going to be doing for the next X hours until you're done. I wanted to love this game, I really did. I've been fascinated with it ever since I first heard about the idea of playing an RPG about an RPG and I did manage to avoid paying full price (Steam sale or Humble Bundle, can't remember which anymore), but after about 6 hours with this game, I just gave up. The story was bad, the writing was bad, the gameplay was cool at first but devolved into being bad by way of mindlessly repetitive (as soon as I had 4 worthwhile party members [balance is another issue with the game, honestly] I found myself unconsciously falling into a pattern of using the same attacks every time because it was pretty much a guaranteed win), the humour (read: pop-culture references) is outdated and forced... The graphics are very nice, though. There's something to be said for well-done 8-bit pixel art. I'd say something about the soundtrack here, but after a while I just turned it off and played my own music. I felt that it added more to the game about a game" experience than generic chiptunes

reviewText: This game is perfect for when I want something fun to distract me from real-life without having to put too much effort into it.  Basically you're controlling a tabletop group of people - DM included.  It's relaxing and turn-based - no button mashing required.  I love the dialog among the different characters you can play.  There are a lot of pop culture references and just enough crude humor to make it entertaining.  There are all sorts of upgrades you can buy with gold to decorate the room the group is playing in (rugs, doors, items for the table like loaded dice and books)  that give bonuses to your characters.  There's a lot of customization for the characters as well.  I got this on sale for $2, but I'd say it's worth the full price.  I can see myself playing this game for a long time.

reviewText: For all lovers of Dungeons&Dragons-styled games, this little gem is quite enjoyable. The story could not be more classic: two to five heroes find themselves in a dungeon, have to escape and then save the kingdom from something dark and evil. It's not the story, though, that really drives KoPaP: as the description says, it's a meta-roleplaying experience with a fair bit of comedy in it. The Dungeon Master and the players are themselves on-screen, and will sometimes make little quips about the D&D system, the campaign story, the enemies and so on.\nOther than the humor, the game offers some nice challenges, nineteen possible players (five of which are unlocked after a quest in the main campaign) to choose from, and different classes to assign them at the start of the campaign (again, some classes are initially unavaillable). All in good ol' D&D-style, complete with dice rolls to verify success or failure in certain task or during travel to decide whether a random encounter occurs.

reviewText:
This is a clever cross platform RPG that plays like a tabletop without the roleplay.

The Good
- This is a really fun game with a lot of backstory.
- There is a lot of freedom to do what you want/need to do.
- There is a ton of replayability because of the large amount of character options.
- Go anywhere you can afford. Grinding isn't the main thrust of the game.

The Bad
- It's an RPG you will be grinding in some cases.
- Once you get a rhythm down it can get repetetive.

Overall this was a surprisingly fun game. I was expecting something cute and shallow, but the sheer amount of stuff there is to do makes this a truly fun game with a nice story.

reviewText:
After seeing a gameplay video on this game i had to give it a try and it delivers. If your into RPGs and tabletop gaming youll enjoy the combat ,options and story this game has to offer.Although some ppl have complained that it is to much of a grind i found that pushing though the story made the game reasonable difficult and well paced.
Although the replay value is weak there is the option of using the different and new classes and items to get some replay value but dont expect to be playing through half a dozen times.
The story is amusing and quirky with alot of pop and nerd culture references littered through out spicing it up and providing alot of humour to keep you going.
I think it was well worth the money i paid and was one of the funnest games ive played this year.

reviewText:
Really bad port. You can't use the keyboard. It is all just clicking. Nothing is different from the mobile version. It is the same exact game. You are not getting anything more in the PC version. Even the quests are the same. I'd really recommend the mobile version to play on the go, the PC version has nothing more to offer.

It's like bringing Angry Birds to PC, it's just the same game, it's not worth more.

Now if they expanded on the game and made it more PC friendly, able to use a keyboard, and made the UI fit better on the screen, it would have been a great game. But it's not. The only difference is that you click instead of touch.

Now I like the game on mobile, but this is just a bad PC port. It's still a good RPG overall though, I really like it.

reviewText:
I love this game.  Everything about it has an old-school feel that blends tabletop RPGs with NES graphics.  There is a lot of grinding in this game, but that's what RPGs are about.  You choose your initial characters from an assortment of people who each have their own unique bonuses, then pick a class for them based on those bonuses and what you want in your party.

If you make challenging enough fights, they require a bit of strategy.  My paladin typically casts a shield to reduce damage by 50%, then increases his threat to draw attention, while my rogue stuns people for 3 turns (thanks to items I have that extend the time by 2 turns).  My mage will either AoE the entire group or fireball for a burning DoT.  My cleric has a powerful single heal, decent group heal, an offensive move called smite, and a debuff on 3 enemy's attack strength.  My newest addition, the berserker, goes berserk (I can't choose his targets but he gains extra damage and regen) and has passives/equipment that boost his crit rate above 30% while also allowing him to heal for 63% of his total damage.  And those are just my 5 classes, there's quite a few more to unlock as you play.

The grinding part comes in two forms.  You'll find yourself moving back and forth to caves often to get grindstones to upgrade your blacksmith.  You'll also want to fight a lot, and grind quests to earn gold.  Gold can be spent buying yourself some equipment at the blacksmith, or on a whole bunch of upgrades to the room you play in, the table you play on, etc.  Purchases made will give your party bonuses, such as higher RNG die rolls, more gold/exp, boosted stats, regen, etc.

There's always something to do in this game.  It can be tedious at times, but the humor of the game, including comments from the game master and party members help to ease this.  Overall, I think it would be a worthy addition to anyone's library who is a fan of old school RPGs.

reviewText:
FIRST OF ALL: the last update deleted my savegame file, so I would recommend to everyone: make backups of your saves, because the updates can reset them. Or turn off the updates for this game only.

This game is fun, has a nice gameplay, unlockable cool characters, lot of achievements, and you need work with your team and use the most useful tables, decorations for you. I was on the end of the game almost, but the update just deleted my save files, so I've got one from the forum, which almost the same like mine was. There are a lot of main and sidequests, you need to upgrade the blacksmith to increase your armor and weapon stats, you can use accessories to get bonuses on your characters and you can switch to another ones and create new ones anytime within the game.

About the serial number, you'll get: You can redeem it on the official Paradox forum, and CAN'T use it in-game as a promo code.

The only wrong thing about this game is the update system, but the game itself is really fun and enjoyable. :)

reviewText:
This game. This game.

If it's not enough yet that you, as a player, are playing players who play a tabletop RPG in which they play their characters while you also play the DM...
...then the amazing amount of references to popular media from Doctor Who to Monty Python to The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy to Star Wars to Back to the Future to too many to name... (Oh, and it also has a bunch of past game references in it.)
...or the wonderful humor that's in the game..
...or the fact you can play with your granny, little brother, and even the pizza guy...
...or at the very least the fact this kind of a gem only shows itself every once in a blue moon should convince you to get this game and play it to death and back.

Seriously, go get it.

reviewText:
This concept sounds good on paper; classic D&D how you remember playing classic D&D. Unfortunately, they left out the game part of D&D.

Essentially, this game is trying to be a humorous game. It's not one you play for a challenge or for fun, but to laugh at. Unfortunately, there are only so many jokes, and there's lots of battling that must be done to go forward. Typically, you'll spend at least ten minutes battling before the next joke or reference, and there's still no guarantee you'll even find it funny.

That might be acceptable if battling was any fun, but unfortunately, it isn't. Every enemy in the game (at least those that I saw) does the exact same thing: Attack on their turn. There is literally nothing to react to except damage. To make matters worse, once you reach level 5 and unlock each of your skills, you can kiss any sense of progression goodbye, since every subsequent level only grants more stat-ups and numerical upgrades to said skills. As for loot and gear, the fun is sucked out of that too; while loot often drops, you have access to a store that sells pretty much any gear you could ever need, so if you're halfway intelligent about visiting it, any loot that drops will always be inferior vendor trash.

Lastly, the game is OBSCENELY grindy. This is the level of grind I would expect from an poorly-made free MMO. Doing almost anything in the game costs coins; often a lot of them. And there are two ways to get coins: A) Win battles, or B) Buy them with real money.

reviewText:
This is one of those games you might give a quick look and pass on, but you'd be making a grave mistake!

If you're into oldschool style turn-based RPGs, pick up KoPP+1.  It's a ton of fun and completely playable in both short doses and long sessions, with a decent story that pokes a lot of fun at the entire table-top RPG genre and many other pop icons.  I purchased it on a whim and quickly fell in love with the quaint graphics, the quirky story, and the RPG style character/equipment progression.

With the amount of time I've sunk into the game (replaying and achievement hunting), I'm forced to give the game a 9/10 rating and highly recommend it!  I wish there were more games like it!

reviewText: Knights of Pen and Paper is quirky, it's enjoyable, and charming, but what's really down there is a game that's downright infuriating. The actual concept of a fun D&D like experience of Knights of Pen and Paper sounds fun and gives it a nice charm to it, but it's simply put down by extremely simple and boring battle mechanics, proceding to follow by annoying dice rolls that become much more of an annoyance then an actual Tabletop game, extreme grinding to the point of just annoyance, and the fact that this game isn't simply something to play a long session on just doesn't give it a justifiable pricetag that's way too expensive for it's own good. It works as a fun mobile game, and I really love the charm and such, but it's still isn't enough to warrant such a purchase of 10 dollars.\n\nI don't know, maybe I am judging it a bit too much, after all, it's roots were from a mobile game. I wouldn't recommend playing this game to many people (Particularly those who don't like mobile games and their microtransaction-like models), but if you like something that can be played in short bursts, is quirky, and simple, this game is for you.

reviewText:
I have played and finished this game and it's lovely. If you have played some dungeon&dragons-like games in the past, it will bring fond memories. Some of the phrases and quips of the characters are spot on, and it all brings you back to that D&D atmosphere very well.

The game principles are quite simple, there is a number of characters, each character has 4 skills, you can loot or buy wearable items and consumables, you can upgrade your weapons. Battles are turn-based, one action per turn. Simple, but also enjoyable and sufficient to help you enjoy yet another D&D adventure.

The questing is well done, there is a main story line, but in any place you have a set of pre-created generic side quests that you can activate at any moment in order to gain more experience or items. You can also set up a custom fight any time. When setting up a fight, you choose how many and which creatures you're going to fight with, and the reward reflects that. I very much like this approach.

There are a few dungeons in the game, which force you to stock up some healing items in the inventory if you want to explore it all, survive, and kill the boss. Again, similar to the D&D theme.

There is good humor in the game, I liked it. After some hours it gets a bit repetitive, but it doesn't hold you up. The music is a bit more of a problem, there are just a few songs in the game, so it gets old quickly. A few more songs would be nice.

Please note I've played this game on an Android tablet, not a PC, so I'm seeing this in a bit different perspective. The greatest benefit of this game for me was that it is an enjoyable game that can easily be played in a public transport during commuting, therefore offline and turn-based. This is an ideal game for your phone or tablet. If you intend to play this on PC, you might expect a bit more complex game mechanics, because you're fully concentrated on the game and you have a big screen. In that case, my opinion might not apply that well.

Highly recommended, especially if you plan to play this on a mobile device (not the Steam version, though, of course).
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
The first thing that really impressed me about KoPaP+1, is that it recognised my eyefinity multi-monitor setup without skipping a beat and started in native resolution on my central (designated no. 1) monitor. The second is the pixel art, which is sumptious and extremely well done.

This is a light and amusing game, paying homage to tabletop RPGs and early 90s cRPGs. If you have reservations in respect of the gold buying facility which is apparently a feature of the tablet versions, it is disabled in the PC version. At first I found the concept a little too meta and self-referential, but the humour grew on me to the point where I found myself laughing and recalling real pen and paper sessions where the GM and players said almost exactly the same things the characters in game were saying.

If you are trying for full completion of achievements, keep in mind that your gold is common between all your saved games, so you can accumulate a good amount of reserves to equip the uber party you create for the 365/465 day completion achieve. This is probably the most elusive while the similarly rare 50 dungeon complete achieve requires no particular strategy except an appetite for doing the same thing over and over again. I've found resetting or upgrading a party which has completed the game and replaying the content at a higher level to be the best way of accumulating gold for such an attempt.

Wait for a decent sale price and you will get at least 25hrs of entertainment for a reasonable sum.

reviewText:
Knights of Pen and Paper +1 is a ported mobile game (with a swath of improvements).  You control a DM and players as you embark on a traditional adventure for glory (and xp and gold and loot).

There are plenty of sidequests to give you a break from the main quest if you desire and you can even just sit and farm monsters if you prefer.

The writing is funny and drops plenty of references.  It can be a little rough at times, as though it was translated or written by a non-native speaker.

However, if you have a tabletop itch to scratch, this will surely satisfy.

reviewText: Paradox Interactive and Behold Studios have created a labor of love with this little game.  This retro style RPG does an amazing job at bringing both the experience of a DnD session and a 90's style JRPG to you with plenty of toungue-in-cheek, modern humor to liven things up.  The classes are all very interesting and provide you with many unique ways to play their skills off of each other.  Battles are quickly paced and fairly designed; if you lose it's your fault.  If I had any critisism at it would be that the game is easier than it should be.  Granted, I grew up in the 90's so I'm a grizzled, RPG veteren at this point but I would still say a small difficulty spike would have raised this game to even greater heights.\n\nIf you have even a smidge of love for Pen and Paper style role play this game is a must purchase.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I think I've played this game enough to give a basic review on the aspects of the game. Now, I'm going to go ahead and say that I like the style of this game, so I may be a bit biased. However, that does not matter as I will still be honest with this game.

My reviews are typically divided into parts. Story, Gameplay, Music/Sounds, and Graphics. So let's get started!

Graphics:
I decided to start with graphics as they are the LEAST important when it comes to this review. This game is featured in 16 bit (I think) and looks quite good. In fact, you basically don't notice how old the graphics look after a while.

Story:
The story of this game is very simple. You are a adventurer. More specifically, you are a D&D player playing a character. You get to create your characters in this game, so you can mix and match until you find the ultimate party! You start with only two members at your table. However, you can pay gold to add three more party members. Each class has a different role. Paladin is the tank. Cleric is the healer. Mage is the support/dps and rogue is the 100% pure blood DPS. After you select your party members and their roles, you start by having your DM tell you that you are in a dark dungeon with no recollection of what happened to you previously. Now, I really don't want to spoil anymore, as fans of D&D (myself included) will have a very fun time with this game.

Gameplay:
This game features a turn-based system using initiative"
date: a real D&D mechanic. Initiative is rolled to see who gets to attack first. Say your character and an ogre were about to have a fight. Your character rolls a 15. The ogre rolls a 9. Therefore
recommended: you would get to go first
hoursPlayed: as you have the higher number. Not only is this game ROLLING in D&D references
voteText: it has it's own unique style. Locations are intresting
helpfulPercent: characters are hilarious and dialogue kept me laughing the entire time. For example
votesHelpful: early in the game you have to kill some rats. The DM says a girl walks up to the party. One of your party members will ask
votesTotal: "Is she hot?" and your DM replies
votesFunny: "Fine. Her charisma is 19." See what I'm saying? So many tabletop references! I guess that's expected. You can upgrade your characters stats using "table items" like food or drinks. There are permanent table items
commentsCount: including a BK crown (which allows you to fight 7 monsters at once) and the Holy Grail (which allows you to have 5 members at your table). There are also "room upgrades". For example
column16: on the left side of your room
column17: you can have a suit of armor
column18: which gives you +20 health on every character until you change it. On the right side
column20:
which makes your table items last longer. You can change your tables too. The gold table gives you more gold. The rock table gives you a larger crit chance. This game is full of customization!

Music/Sounds:
Music and sounds are
column23:
delivering some tunes I've been humming since the day I got the game. The title screen is my personal favorite though!

OVERALL RATING:
This game is a fantastic game with a lot of comedy. Over all I'd give Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition a 10/10 for it's effort to contribute to the D&D society and give you some good laughs along the way!

Conclusion:

I hope you enjoyed my review of Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition! The DLC for the game
column25: is out now! I will be reviewing it once I get the chance to play the DLC! Cya next time folks!"

reviewText: As far as turn based adventures go, this one is one of the most creative I've played. Simple battle style, but plenty of mobs and heroes to choose from and lots to explore. I'm a big fan of anything with upgrades, and this one has many, as well as little easter eggs to unlock. It's not meant to be taken seriously like a lot of fantasy turn-based strategy, which is what makes it so spectacular.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
As a person who understands the basics of Dungeons And Dragons, this game makes me feel as if I actually know a lot about D&D. This game takes itself lightly by breaking the fourth wall to the players of the game as well as the fourth wall to the person playing the game. The short time I've played this game makes me want to keep playing to see how the story fully pans out. The quality of the story so far (up to level 25) is quite good and is filled with humor and stereotypical quest missions. The missions can get repetitive if you don't customize the wave difficulty, I found that mechanic to be especially usefull in making the game more challenging. The upgrade mechanics are well rounded and I have found no problem with them. If you aren't a fan of the Turn Based games then this game is DEFINITELY NOT FOR YOU. But the fans of TBS and people who can appreciate the gamestyle, my favorite gamestyle is Wavedefense/Towerdefense, then this game offers alot to you. I have not been disapointed by this game at all.

Cost to Gameplay Ratio (.8 is an Okay ratio) : $10 - 6(+6 hours of completing the game fully)
Replay Value: 9/10
Story Quality: 6/10 (the story itself isn't so great but the small sidemissions and other things are great)
Humor Value: 8/10
Technical Quality: 10/10
Graphics Quality: 8/10 (it is in the pixel artstyle (did not subtract b/c of the pixel artsyle))

OVERALL RATING: 8/10

I purchased this game in a bundlestars bundle and I'm glad this game was in it, I didn't buy the bundle for this game at the time, but after playing it I would have been mad if I didn't purchase the bundle.

reviewText:
This game is somewhat casual and is, perhaps, a bit better suited for moble devices. I've played it on my tablet much more than on this format. But, it's the same game (as far as i can tell), so it doesn't really matter - whatever suits you.

In any case, it's a simple, well thought out, and fun game that was obviously made with care and love. That's not to say that there isn't some depth, but certainly anyone can play it and like it - on some level.

Whatever the level of interest, it would be utterly unfair to slam a game like this. Any fair minded person would have to admit that it's quite good at what it's trying to do - excellent, in fact.

I would also mention that the humor and inside jokes are amusing and add favorably to the experience.

Recommended.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Knights of Pen and Paper allows me to do something that I've always wanted to do in a fantasy setting.  I am able to control a few characters on one table with clear cut differences between them.  It is simple enough for almost anyone to understand, and it is a pretty good game to play if you like indie, small time games.  It has a lot of exploration that I haven't done.  Even though you repeat quests a lot, the quests are different every time with different people.

The basis of the game is that you are playing against whatever the DM throws at you.  You are at your table, with your players and your classes they each encapsulate.  The classes are basic (Mage, Druid, Rogue, Warrior, Cleric, etc.) and the players themselves each have a special characteristic about them (the Jock has +? HP, the Alien regenrates +1 MP every turn, etc.).  It  Buying objects for the DM room, table, general location allows the players to get better points, experience, health, etc.  So instead of buffing singular characters, you are buffing all characters.  It's a fun game ultimately, and one that I will play frequently.

If you don't like pixelated gfxs, or table top scenarios at all, this might not be your cup of tea.

INGREDIENTS:
1 cup butter, softened
1 cup white sugar
1 cup packed brown sugar
2 eggs
2 teaspoons vanilla extract
3 cups all-purpose flour
1 teaspoon baking soda
2 teaspoons hot water
1/2 teaspoon salt
2 cups semisweet chocolate chips
1 cup chopped walnuts
DIRECTIONS:
1.	Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
2.	Cream together the butter, white sugar, and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla. Dissolve baking soda in hot water. Add to batter along with salt. Stir in flour, chocolate chips, and nuts. Drop by large spoonfuls onto ungreased pans.
3.	Bake for about 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until edges are nicely browned.

reviewText:
The game is really nice.

It's a classical RPG with classes and different perks (different player characters with different passives) you can choose from.
It's a funny homage to all Pen & Paper playing people out there. You can boost your stats ingame with Fastfood, Coke, Beer, Candy and Pizza ordering it directly via the ingame shop, where you pay with gold found in the game.

The game is hard, but fair.

There are a lot of eastereggs in it. Everywhere you find little hints or textparts that will remind you of other great games or movies.

Only negative thing was the fact that there are only 2 dungeons. But perhaps more will be added to a later point. There will be a few DLC's I heard.

So if you like great classical RPG's this game is a must have.

reviewText:
It only took 30+ years for someone to make an RPG game about D&D, from the third person perspective.

I can't stress enough how much I love this game. It's just so unique and lovable.

The dialogue is great and the amount of things you can do in the game are ridiculous. One thing I love is that the game rewards you for pushing yourself to the limit. The harder you make it on yourself, the more EXP and Gold you'll earn, making the game easier overall, later down the line. But give yourself an easy time and the game will become brutal at the later stages.

There are multiple classes (Some are secret. Shhhh...) to choose from and multiple players for those characters. For example, the Hipster playing as a Druid or your Grandma playing as a Necromancer. Make your own party and formulate your own way to win. Anything is possible. Single target DOT team. An AoE team. 'Classic' 1 tank, 3 DPS and a healer. Whatever you want to do.

There are microtransactions apparent in the game, but they are about as pointless as a chocolate radiator. Best not to bother with them. In fact, just forget I said anything at all.

Like classic RPG's? Buy it. Have some fun. 10/10.

reviewText: As an avid fan of the D20 system and DnD series(I play Ver. 3.5 currently) created my the Great and Powerful Melevolence himself, Gary Gygax, I loved the pitch off the bat! It's in retro 8-bit animation style, leaving room for extra nostalgia for those who used to play the old DnD Game Boy games and NES games(amongst other titles too!). The story(campaign) is funny, edgy, tense and just an all around perfect adventure. The aspects that I enjoy most from this game is Armor and Weapons upgrading through the Blacksmith(which you can upgrade with donations of materials, etc.) and that you CHOOSE how big of a fight you get yourself and your party into. It's like having a voyeur POV of a very long DnD campaign, and YOU CONTROL IT! What's not to like?! :3

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I have played and finished this game and it's lovely. If you have played some dungeon&dragons-like games in the past, it will bring fond memories. Some of the phrases and quips of the characters are spot on, and it all brings you back to that D&D atmosphere very well.

The game principles are quite simple, there is a number of characters, each character has 4 skills, you can loot or buy wearable items and consumables, you can upgrade your weapons. Battles are turn-based, one action per turn. Simple, but also enjoyable and sufficient to help you enjoy yet another D&D adventure.

The questing is well done, there is a main story line, but in any place you have a set of pre-created generic side quests that you can activate at any moment in order to gain more experience or items. You can also set up a custom fight any time. When setting up a fight, you choose how many and which creatures you're going to fight with, and the reward reflects that. I very much like this approach.

There are a few dungeons in the game, which force you to stock up some healing items in the inventory if you want to explore it all, survive, and kill the boss. Again, similar to the D&D theme.

There is good humor in the game, I liked it. After some hours it gets a bit repetitive, but it doesn't hold you up. The music is a bit more of a problem, there are just a few songs in the game, so it gets old quickly. A few more songs would be nice.

Please note I've played this game on an Android tablet, not a PC, so I'm seeing this in a bit different perspective. The greatest benefit of this game for me was that it is an enjoyable game that can easily be played in a public transport during commuting, therefore offline and turn-based. This is an ideal game for your phone or tablet. If you intend to play this on PC, you might expect a bit more complex game mechanics, because you're fully concentrated on the game and you have a big screen. In that case, my opinion might not apply that well.

Highly recommended, especially if you plan to play this on a mobile device (not the Steam version, though, of course).
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
The first thing that really impressed me about KoPaP+1, is that it recognised my eyefinity multi-monitor setup without skipping a beat and started in native resolution on my central (designated no. 1) monitor. The second is the pixel art, which is sumptious and extremely well done.

This is a light and amusing game, paying homage to tabletop RPGs and early 90s cRPGs. If you have reservations in respect of the gold buying facility which is apparently a feature of the tablet versions, it is disabled in the PC version. At first I found the concept a little too meta and self-referential, but the humour grew on me to the point where I found myself laughing and recalling real pen and paper sessions where the GM and players said almost exactly the same things the characters in game were saying.

If you are trying for full completion of achievements, keep in mind that your gold is common between all your saved games, so you can accumulate a good amount of reserves to equip the uber party you create for the 365/465 day completion achieve. This is probably the most elusive while the similarly rare 50 dungeon complete achieve requires no particular strategy except an appetite for doing the same thing over and over again. I've found resetting or upgrading a party which has completed the game and replaying the content at a higher level to be the best way of accumulating gold for such an attempt.

Wait for a decent sale price and you will get at least 25hrs of entertainment for a reasonable sum.

reviewText: Knights of Pen and Paper +1 is a ‚Äúroleplaying game‚Äù, but in truth it has very little roleplaying in it; while this is common to many ‚ÄúRPGs,‚Äù this game takes it to an all-new level. The conceit behind the game is that you are sitting at a table with your game master with a group of friends, and that you are going through a campaign. The players are indeed all seated around a table, with the game master on the far side of the table dictating what is going on. It is a very clever idea, but unfortunately the game fails to execute on it at all; instead, the game is a pure hack-and-slash fest which tries to spice things up with humor and gaming references but falls flat because, quite frankly, everyone sitting around a table has already not only made all of these references, but done it better. The plot is every bad game of D&D you've ever played, every unoriginal campaign rolled into one, and it is played straight - sure, one could argue that it is almost comically bad, but it is painfully bad, like Batman and Robin, rather than camp.\n\nAs the gameplay itself is thoroughly hack and slash, purely about cutting your way through an extremely large number of monsters using extremely simplistic turn-based combat reminiscent of many JRPGs, with no real coherent or interesting story to speak of, there is little to recommend this game as anything but a time waster, and even there, you can do far better. There's nothing that this game doesn't show you in the first hour, and there's nothing in that first hour worth taking. While the basic underlying idea of having a bunch of players playing a roleplaying game is an interesting one, this game is a total failure at it. Maybe someday, someone will take this idea and do something good with it, but this is not that game.

reviewText:
I wasn't expecting to like this game as much as I have been. In all honesty, this is a fun little game! There's several different kinds of combinations you can make with your characters, and there's also new classes to unlock along the way, which just adds to the replayability to see all the different kinds of combinations. The gameplay is incredibly simple, but it's fun to kind of 'multitask' as you're doing something in the background while also playing this game in windowed mode.

The game also kind of lets you 'choose' how the game progresses, as you're essentially the Dungeon Master. You can choose what kind of enemy to fight, and also how many of them. This allows for you to play at your own pace!

You can also add on more characters as you go along (up to five in total), but you'd have to level them up all the way from level one, which can be kind of a pain, but, ya know, comes with the territory. The same applies for whenever you unlock a class and want to use them. You'd have to level them up from level one. Kind of sucks, but once again, this is supposed to be reminiscent of old-school RPG's. You want to play that new class you just unlocked? Gotta start 'em from the beginning.

Overall, even though I'm only a few hours into the game, I still want to play it and progress even further. This game could definitely keep you occupied for a while, especially if you're looking for a more traditional, old-school RPG. Check it out!

reviewText:
This game is addicting, and amazingly fun. For those who have played D&D, and either do not anymore, or just love the party aspect (but hate organizing times to play), this IS the game for you!

Do not let the D&D reference mislead you, it is not quite as in depth and does not have a million skills/feats/spells, but it has just enough to keep the interest, while not overplaying it all, and DEFINITELY does not have the time devotion and endless hours of character sheet organization... and best of all, it only takes one player, not a DM+5.

The tables are customizable, the ornaments in the room, the door, the artifacts on the table, the DM itself, I mean, you can even buy soda and chips and such in the store, to place on the table for your characters to get bonuses for XX amount of time! If only some D&D games would follow suit with the style of this game.

reviewText:
If you're an old school fan of Dungeons & Dragons and don't have the time to play an epic RPG, this game is for you. You do NOT need to buy any microtransactions in this game as long as you manage you money ok (read the guides and use +gold bonus modifiers). I like the fact that you have the option to play in different screen resolutions as well as in a windowed mode where you can multitask.

This game takes turn-based RPG to its roots. Newer gamers may not appreciate it, but it is right for older gamers with busy lives. It is sprinkled with pop culture and various references throughout the game. It may get repetitive at times, but there are various classes to keep things fresh.

The game doesn't do a very good job in explaining that you can mine rocks in caves for grindstone, and then take the stones to a town to raise the XP of the blacksmith. I would not suggest attempting to level up weapons and armors until later in the game since the success rate is so low. Reading the tips and guides will make your experience more enjoyable and you won't be wasting your hard-earned gold (since gold is used for everything, including travel).

reviewText:
A game that obliterates your grasp of time.  This game should not be initiated late in the evening as you will almost always find yourself still playing by one in the morning.  New players begin with five seats, but can only afford to fill two of them at first.  Choose carefully which skills your heroes will specialize in, don't make jack-of-all-trades; because even though you can 'usually' controll the strength of the mob parties you will fight, you can't afford to be unspecialized.   I'm loving this game so much I can barely elequate.

Humor:  Casual, but usually satisfactory, 8-bit cliches and DM wit, 7/10
Music: Fits the game, it's 8-bit rpg themes, what is there to say?  6/10

Controls: Smoothe as giant moth fur.  In combat, whoevers turn it is, no need to click 'attack' and then select which enemy to attack, just click the enemy and, wham, a virtual 'rush' mechanic for mopping up weaker mobs.  The world map could've been given a bit more compensation room at the fringes because you click and drag the map to move it around and some locations ARE right at the edges, just a minor irritation there, could've been fixed with the ability to zoom out, but they didn't include that.  There were other things, but overall, deserves a 9/10

Visuals: In an 8-bit tabletop rpg sim, all you can ask for is a great color pallete, and it's in there.  8/10

This game is virtually always in Ironman mode, constantly autosaving, so even if you hit esc enough times to terminate the game, no need to freak for your progress' sake :)

That's enough from me, enjoy, my comerade gamers, *drops the mic*

reviewText: This is a distressingly accurate tabletop simulator.\n\nIt sort of feels like Dungeons of Dredmore Does Tabletop" to me.  The sense of humor is mildly more down-to-earth
date: the battles are turn-based RPG style (with no tile-based / movement aspect)
recommended: but the character progression is similar and the visual style reminds me of it in a good way.  The actual game mechanics are heavily simplified
hoursPlayed: and seem to be based as much off of japanese computer RPGs as they are off of any particular tabletop game.  The players for your party bicker and banter at eachother with one-liners now and again
voteText: I've found at least one quest that seems specifically designed to encourage lateral thinking ("why go to the area ten levels higher than you
helpfulPercent: when you can /buy/ the quest drop at a store?")
votesHelpful:
and there seems to be some kind of over-arching storyline that I haven't really gotten far with.

DoD is on my computer as sort of an equivalent / replacement for solitaire -- Knights of Pen and Paper is happily getting added into the same category.

[Edit]  On later reflection
votesTotal: it also reminds me of MMO's with the get quest / kill X things / get next quest / move to new area dynamic.  Unfortunately
votesFunny: they roam all over the world map and you can only hold one of them at a time -- meaning it's impossible to prioritize what order you want to do them in
commentsCount: particularly when many of them are multi-stage with each step in a different place.  There is very little strategy.  That said
column16: it's still a good mindless game if you like the combat style."

reviewText:
The fact that I've amassed 30 hours on this since its most recent sale a week ago should suggest just how much I'm enjoying this game. While at times it has seemed to drag on (particularly with some of the fetch quests, but what game with fetch quests DOESN'T drag at those points really), I have thoroughly enjoyed the experience of what is effectively D'n'D in video game form.

I think the one thing I've enjoyed the most about this experience though is that you control exactly how easy/hard the game is for more or less the duration of the game. For about 90% of the battles, you decide just how many monsters you face, whether you make it easy on yourself and just take on one small bat for minimal but easy exp, or whether you take on a horde of Invaders for major risk/reward exp/gold - a concept which I thought is pretty damn neat. Along with being able to change your party at any point in the game (with more classes to unlock as you playthrough), you can really make the experience your own every time and try all sorts of weird and wonderful combinations.

Fun addicting title with neat graphics and a good soundtrack that I'm sure I'll be playing for many many moons to come.
